TYPE => $1
	, SCHEMA => $2
	, NAME => $3
	, METHOD => $4
	, ESTIMATE_ROWS => $5
	, ESTIMATE_PERCENT => $6
	, METHOD_OPT => $7
	, PARTNAME => $8

ATTACH_SESSION.descriptionText: This procedure notifies the debug session about the target program.

CONTINUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.CONTINUE (
   run_info       IN OUT runtime_info,
   breakflags     IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   info_requested IN     BINARY_INTEGER := NULL)
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
CONTINUE.descriptionText: This function passes the given breakflags (a mask of the events that are of interest) to Probe in the target process. It tells Probe to continue execution of the target process, and it waits until the target process runs to completion or signals an event.

DEBUG_ON.descriptionText: This procedure marks the target session so that all PL/SQL is run in debug mode. This must be done before any debugging can take place.

DELETE_OER_BREAKPOINT.descriptionText: This function deletes an OER breakpoint.

DETACH_SESSION.descriptionText: This procedure stops debugging the target program. This procedure may be called at any time, but it does not notify the target session that the debug session is detaching itself, and it does not terminate execution of the target session. Therefore, care should be taken to ensure that the target session does not hang itself.

DISABLE_BREAKPOINT.descriptionText: This function makes an existing breakpoint inactive but leaves it in place.

ENABLE_BREAKPOINT.descriptionText: This function is the reverse of disabling. This enables a previously disabled breakpoint.

EXECUTE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.EXECUTE (
   what         IN VARCHAR2,
   frame#       IN BINARY_INTEGER,
   bind_results IN BINARY_INTEGER,
   results      IN OUT NOCOPY dbms_debug_vc2coll,
   errm         IN OUT NOCOPY VARCHAR2);
EXECUTE.descriptionText: This procedure executes SQL or PL/SQL code in the target session. The target session is assumed to be waiting at a breakpoint (or other event). The call to DBMS_DEBUG.EXECUTE occurs in the debug session, which then asks the target session to execute the code.

GET_INDEXES.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.GET_INDEXES (
   varname   IN  VARCHAR2,
   frame#    IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   handle    IN  program_info,
   entries   OUT index_table) 
RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
GET_INDEXES.descriptionText: Given a name of a variable or parameter, this function returns the set of its indexes, if it is an indexed table. An error is returned if it is not an indexed table.

GET_LINE_MAP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.GET_LINE_MAP (
   program                IN   program_info,
   maxline                OUT  BINARY_INTEGER,
   number_of_entry_points OUT  BINARY_INTEGER,
   linemap                OUT  RAW)
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
GET_LINE_MAP.descriptionText: This function finds line and entrypoint information about a program so that a debugger can determine the source lines at which it is possible to place breakpoints.

GET_MORE_SOURCE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.GET_MORE_SOURCE (
   buffer          IN OUT VARCHAR2,
   buflen          IN BINARY_INTEGER,
   piece#          IN BINARY_INTEGER);
GET_MORE_SOURCE.descriptionText: When source does not fit in the buffer provided by that version of the SHOW_SOURCE Procedures which produce a formatted buffer, this procedure provides additional source.

GET_RUNTIME_INFO.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.GET_RUNTIME_INFO (
   info_requested  IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   run_info        OUT runtime_info)
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
GET_RUNTIME_INFO.descriptionText: This function returns information about the current program. It is only needed if the info_requested parameter to SYNCHRONIZE or CONTINUE was set to 0.

GET_TIMEOUT_BEHAVIOUR.descriptionText: This procedure returns the current timeout behavior. This call is made in the target session.

GET_VALUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.GET_VALUE (
   variable_name  IN  VARCHAR2,
   frame#         IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   scalar_value   OUT VARCHAR2,
   format         IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL)
RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
GET_VALUE.descriptionText: This function gets a value from the currently-running program. There are two overloaded GET_VALUE functions.

INITIALIZE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.INITIALIZE (
   debug_session_id  IN VARCHAR2       := NULL, 
   diagnostics       IN BINARY_INTEGER := 0)
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
INITIALIZE.descriptionText: This function initializes the target session for debugging.

PING.descriptionText: This procedure pings the target session to prevent it from timing out. Use this procedure when execution is suspended in the target session, for example at a breakpoint.

PRINT_BACKTRACE.descriptionText: This procedure prints a backtrace listing of the current execution stack. This should only be called if a program is currently running.

PRINT_INSTANTIATIONS.descriptionText: This procedure returns a list of the packages that have been instantiated in the current session.

PROBE_VERSION.descriptionText: This procedure returns the version number of DBMS_DEBUG on the server.

SELF_CHECK.descriptionText: This procedure performs an internal consistency check. SELF_CHECK also runs a communications test to ensure that the Probe processes are able to communicate.

SET_BREAKPOINT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.SET_BREAKPOINT (
   program     IN  program_info,
   line#       IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   breakpoint# OUT BINARY_INTEGER,
   fuzzy       IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0,
   iterations  IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0)
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
SET_BREAKPOINT.descriptionText: This function sets a breakpoint in a program unit, which persists for the current session. Execution pauses if the target program reaches the breakpoint.

SET_OER_BREAKPOINT.descriptionText: This function sets an OER breakpoint.

SET_TIMEOUT.descriptionText: This function sets the timeout value and returns the new timeout value.

SET_TIMEOUT_BEHAVIOUR.descriptionText: This procedure tells Probe what to do with the target session when a timeout occurs. This call is made in the target session.

SET_VALUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.SET_VALUE (
   frame#               IN binary_integer,
   assignment_statement IN varchar2) 
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;

DBMS_DEBUG.SET_VALUE (
   handle               IN program_info,
   assignment_statement IN VARCHAR2) 
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
SET_VALUE.descriptionText: This function sets a value in the currently-running program. There are two overloaded SET_VALUE functions.

SHOW_BREAKPOINTS.descriptionText: There are two overloaded procedures that return a listing of the current breakpoints. There are three overloaded SHOW_BREAKPOINTS procedures.

SHOW_FRAME_SOURCE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.SHOW_FRAME_SOURCE (
   first_line  IN            BINARY_INTEGER,
   last_line   IN            BINARY_INTEGER,
   source      IN OUT NOCOPY vc2_table,
   frame_num   IN            BINARY_INTEGER);
SHOW_FRAME_SOURCE.descriptionText: The procedure gets the source code. There are two overloaded SHOW_SOURCE procedures.

SHOW_SOURCE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.SHOW_SOURCE (
   first_line  IN   BINARY_INTEGER,
   last_line   IN   BINARY_INTEGER,
   source      OUT  vc2_table);

DBMS_DEBUG.SHOW_SOURCE (
   first_line   IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   last_line    IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   window       IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   print_arrow  IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   buffer       IN OUT VARCHAR2,
   buflen       IN     BINARY_INTEGER,
   pieces       OUT    BINARY_INTEGER);
SHOW_SOURCE.descriptionText: The procedure gets the source code. There are two overloaded SHOW_SOURCE procedures.

SYNCHRONIZE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.SYNCHRONIZE (
   run_info       OUT  runtime_info,
   info_requested IN   BINARY_INTEGER := NULL)
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
SYNCHRONIZE.descriptionText: This function waits until the target program signals an event. If info_requested is not NULL, then it calls GET_RUNTIME_INFO.

TARGET_PROGRAM_RUNNING.descriptionText: This procedure returns TRUE if the target session is currently executing a stored procedure, or FALSE if it is not.

IS_TRIGGER_FIRE_ONCE_INTERNAL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEBUG.IS_TRIGGER_FIRE_ONCE_INTERNAL(
        TRIG_OWNER IN VARCHAR2 
        TRIG_NAME IN VARCHAR2 
)
return BINARY_INTEGER

ANYDATA_ARG.descriptionText: This procedure provides the data that is to be passed to a deferred remote procedure call. Depending upon the type of the data that you must pass to a procedure, you must call one of the following procedures for each argument to the procedure.

CALL.bodyNoDefault:
schema_name => $1
	, package_name => $2
	, proc_name => $3
	, arg_count => $4
	, nodes => $5
	, group_name => $6
CALL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER.CALL (
   schema_name       IN   VARCHAR2,
   package_name      IN   VARCHAR2,
   proc_name         IN   VARCHAR2,
   arg_count         IN   NATURAL,
   { nodes           IN   node_list_t 
   | group_name      IN   VARCHAR2 :=''});
CALL.descriptionText: This procedure builds a deferred call to a remote procedure.

COMMIT_WORK.descriptionText: This procedure performs a transaction commit after checking for well-formed deferred remote procedure calls.

TRANSACTION.descriptionText: This procedure indicates the start of a new deferred transaction. If you omit this call, then Oracle considers your first call to DBMS_DEFER.CALL to be the start of a new transaction.

GET_ARG_FORM.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_QUERY.GET_ARG_FORM (
   callno                IN   NUMBER,
   arg_no                IN   NUMBER,
   deferred_tran_id      IN   VARCHAR2)
  RETURN NUMBER;
GET_ARG_FORM.descriptionText: This function returns the character set form of a deferred call parameter.

GET_ARG_TYPE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_QUERY.GET_ARG_TYPE (
   callno            IN   NUMBER,
   arg_no            IN   NUMBER,
   deferred_tran_id  IN   VARCHAR2)
  RETURN NUMBER;
GET_ARG_TYPE.descriptionText: This function determines the type of an argument in a deferred call. The type of the deferred remote procedure call (RPC) parameter is returned.

GET_CALL_ARGS.bodyNoDefault:
callno => $1
	, startarg => $2
	, argcnt => $3
	, argsize => $4
	, tran_db => $5
	, tran_id => $6
	, date_fmt => $7
	, types => $8
	, forms => $9
	, vals => $10
GET_CALL_ARGS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_QUERY.GET_CALL_ARGS (
   callno    IN  NUMBER,
   startarg  IN  NUMBER := 1,
   argcnt    IN  NUMBER,       
   argsize   IN  NUMBER,     
   tran_db   IN  VARCHAR2, 
   tran_id   IN  VARCHAR2, 
   date_fmt  IN  VARCHAR2,

DBMS_DEFER_QUERY.GET_CALL_ARGS (

   startarg       IN  NUMBER := 1,
   argcnt         IN  NUMBER,       
   argsize        IN  NUMBER,     
   tran_id        IN  VARCHAR2,

   forms          OUT TYPE_ARY,
   vals           OUT VAL_ARY);
DBMS_DEFER_QUERY.GET_CALL_ARGS (
   callno         IN  NUMBER,
   startarg       IN  NUMBER := 1,
   argcnt         IN  NUMBER,       
   argsize        IN  NUMBER,     
   tran_id        IN  VARCHAR2, 
   date_fmt       IN  VARCHAR2, 
   time_fmt       IN  VARCHAR2, 
   ttz_fmt        IN  VARCHAR2, 
   timestamp_fmt  IN  VARCHAR2, 
   tstz_fmt       IN  VARCHAR2, 
   tsltz_fmt      IN  VARCHAR2, 
   types          OUT TYPE_ARY,  
   forms          OUT TYPE_ARY,
   vals           OUT VAL_ARY);
GET_CALL_ARGS.descriptionText: This procedure returns the text version of the various arguments for the specified call. The text version is limited to the first 2000 bytes.

GET_DATATYPE_ARG.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_QUERY.GET_datatype_ARG (
   callno             IN   NUMBER,
   arg_no             IN   NUMBER,
   deferred_tran_id   IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL)
  RETURN datatype;
GET_DATATYPE_ARG.descriptionText: This function determines the value of an argument in a deferred call.

GET_OBJECT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_QUERY.GET_OBJECT-NULL_VECTOR_ARG (
   callno                IN   NUMBER,
   arg_no                IN   NUMBER,
   deferred_tran_id      IN   VARCHAR2)
  RETURN SYSTEM.REPCAT$_OBJECT_NULL_VECTOR;
GET_OBJECT.descriptionText: This function returns the type information for a column object, including the type owner, name, and hashcode.

ADD_DEFAULT_DEST.descriptionText: This procedure adds a destination database to the DEFDEFAULTDEST data dictionary view.

CLEAR_PROP_STATISTICS.descriptionText: This procedure clears the propagation statistics in the DEFSCHEDULE data dictionary view. When this procedure is executed successfully, all statistics in this view are returned to zero and statistic gathering starts fresh.

DELETE_DEF_DESTINATION.descriptionText: This procedure removes a destination database from the DEFSCHEDULE view.

DELETE_DEFAULT_DEST.descriptionText: This procedure removes a destination database from the DEFDEFAULTDEST view.

DELETE_ERROR.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a transaction from the DEFERROR view.

DELETE_TRAN.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a transaction from the DEFTRANDEST view. If there are no other DEFTRANDEST or DEFERROR entries for the transaction, then the transaction is deleted from the DEFTRAN and DEFCALL views as well.

DISABLED.descriptionText: This function determines whether propagation of the deferred transaction queue from the current site to a specified site is enabled. The DISABLED function returns TRUE if the deferred remote procedure call (RPC) queue is disabled for the specified destination.

EXCLUDE_PUSH.descriptionText: This function acquires an exclusive lock that prevents deferred transaction PUSH (either serial or parallel). This function performs a commit when acquiring the lock. The lock is acquired with RELEASE_ON_COMMIT => TRUE, so that pushing of the deferred transaction queue can resume after the next commit.

EXECUTE_ERROR.descriptionText: This procedure reexecutes a deferred transaction that did not initially complete successfully in the security context of the original receiver of the transaction.

EXECUTE_ERROR_AS_USER.descriptionText: This procedure reexecutes a deferred transaction that did not initially complete successfully. Each transaction is executed in the security context of the connected user.

PURGE.bodyNoDefault:
purge_method => $1
	, rollback_segment => $2
	, startup_seconds => $3
	, execution_seconds => $4
	, delay_seconds => $5
	, transaction_count => $6
	, write_trace => $7
PURGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_SYS.PURGE (
   purge_method         IN  BINARY_INTEGER := purge_method_quick,
   rollback_segment     IN  VARCHAR2       := NULL,
   startup_seconds      IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0,
   execution_seconds    IN  BINARY_INTEGER := seconds_infinity,
   delay_seconds        IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0,
   transaction_count    IN  BINARY_INTEGER := transactions_infinity,
   write_trace          IN  BOOLEAN        := NULL);
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
PURGE.descriptionText: This function purges pushed transactions from the deferred transaction queue at your current master site or materialized view site.

PUSH.bodyNoDefault:
destination => $1
	, parallelism => $2
	, heap_size => $3
	, stop_on_error => $4
	, write_trace => $5
	, startup_seconds => $6
	, execution_seconds => $7
	, delay_seconds => $8
	, transaction_count => $9
	, delivery_order_limit => $10
PUSH.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_SYS.PUSH (
   destination          IN  VARCHAR2,
   parallelism          IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0,
   heap_size            IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0,
   stop_on_error        IN  BOOLEAN        := FALSE,
   write_trace          IN  BOOLEAN        := FALSE,
   startup_seconds      IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0,
   execution_seconds    IN  BINARY_INTEGER := seconds_infinity,
   delay_seconds        IN  BINARY_INTEGER := 0,
   transaction_count    IN  BINARY_INTEGER := transactions_infinity,
   delivery_order_limit IN  NUMBER         := delivery_order_infinity)
  RETURN BINARY_INTEGER;
PUSH.descriptionText: This function forces a deferred remote procedure call (RPC) queue at your current master site or materialized view site to be pushed (propagated) to a remote site using either serial or parallel propagation.

REGISTER_PROPAGATOR.descriptionText: This procedure registers the specified user as the propagator for the local database. It also grants the following privileges to the specified user (so that the user can create wrappers):

SCHEDULE_PURGE.bodyNoDefault:

SCHEDULE_PURGE.descriptionText: This procedure schedules a job to purge pushed transactions from the deferred transaction queue at your current master site or materialized view site. You should schedule one purge job.

SET_DISABLED.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DEFER_SYS.SET_DISABLED (
   destination   IN   VARCHAR2,
   disabled      IN   BOOLEAN := TRUE,
   catchup       IN   RAW := '00',
   override      IN   BOOLEAN := FALSE);
SET_DISABLED.descriptionText: To disable or enable propagation of the deferred transaction queue from the current site to a specified destination site. If the disabled parameter is TRUE, then the procedure disables propagation to the specified destination and future invocations of PUSH do not push the deferred remote procedure call (RPC) queue. SET_DISABLED eventually affects a session already pushing the queue to the specified destination, but does not affect sessions appending to the queue with DBMS_DEFER.

UNREGISTER_PROPAGATOR.descriptionText: To unregister a user as the propagator from the local database. This procedure:

UNSCHEDULE_PURGE.descriptionText: This procedure stops automatic purges of pushed transactions from the deferred transaction queue at a master site or materialized view site.

UNSCHEDULE_PUSH.descriptionText: This procedure stops automatic pushes of the deferred transaction queue from a master site or materialized view site to a remote site.

DESCRIBE_PROCEDURE.descriptionText: The procedure DESCRIBE_PROCEDURE provides a brief description of a PL/SQL stored procedure. It takes the name of a stored procedure and returns information about each parameter of that procedure.

INITIATE_FS_FAILOVER.descriptionText: Use this procedure to specify a condition string that, when encountered by an application, allows the application to request that a fast-start failover be invoked.

DESCRIBE_DIMENSION.descriptionText: This procedure displays the definition of the dimension, including dimension name, levels, hierarchies, and attributes. It displays the output using the DBMS_OUTPUT package.

VALIDATE_DIMENSION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DIMENSION.VALIDATE_DIMENSION (
   dimension               IN VARCHAR2,
   incremental             IN BOOLEAN := TRUE,
   check_nulls             IN BOOLEAN := FALSE,
   statement_id            IN VARCHAR2 := NULL );
VALIDATE_DIMENSION.descriptionText: This procedure verifies that the relationships specified in a dimension are valid. The rowid for any row that is found to be invalid will be stored in the table DIMENSION_EXCEPTIONS in the use\'s schema.

ALLOW_ALL.descriptionText: This procedure empties the Trusted Servers List and specifies that all servers that are members of a trusted domain in an enterprise directory service and that are in the same domain are allowed access.

ALLOW_SERVER.descriptionText: This procedure ensures that the specified server is considered trusted (even if you have previously specified "deny all").

DENY_ALL.descriptionText: This procedure empties the Trusted Servers List and specifies that all servers are denied access.

DENY_SERVER.descriptionText: This procedure ensures that the specified server is considered untrusted (even if you have previously specified allow all).

CLONEDB_RENAMEFILE.descriptionText: This procedure is used to rename datafiles that were pointing to the backup set to the actual file name in cloned database. The srcfile is the file name that represents the data file in the backup image copy or a read-only storage snapshot. The destfile destination file path must point to a NFS volume where cloneDB datafiles will be created. When the procedure is run successfully, the control file record is updated with the new datafile name.

BEGIN_PREPARE.descriptionText: This procedure starts a prepare window. Once a prepare window is started successfully, the database property\'DST_UPGRADE_STAT\' is set to\'PREPAR\', and the database property\'SECONDARY_TT_VERSIO\' is set to a new timezone version.

BEGIN_UPGRADE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DST.BEGIN_UPGRADE (
   new_version                IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   error_on_overlap_time      IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE,
   error_on_nonexisting_time  IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE);
BEGIN_UPGRADE.descriptionText: This procedure starts an upgrade window. When an upgraded window is started successfully, the TSTZ data in the dictionary tables is upgraded to reflect the new timezone version, and the database property\'DST_UPGRADE_STAT\' is set to\'UPGRAD\'. Once BEGIN_UPGRADE has been performed successfully, the user must re-start the database. After a successful restart, the database property\'PRIMARY_TT_VERSIO\' is the new timezone version, and\'SECONDARY_TT_VERSIO\' is the old timezone version.

CREATE_AFFECTED_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a table that has the schema shown in the comments for the FIND_AFFECTED_TABLES Procedure.

CREATE_ERROR_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a log error table which has the following schema:

CREATE_TRIGGER_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a table that has the following schema.

END_UPGRADE.descriptionText: This procedure ends an upgrade window. An upgraded window is ended if all the affected user tables have been upgraded. Otherwise, the OUT parameter num_of_failures indicates how many tables have not been converted.

FIND_AFFECTED_TABLES.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DST.FIND_AFFECTED_TABLES (
   affected_tables             IN  VARCHAR2 =: 'sys.dst$affected_tables',
   log_errors                  IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE,
   log_errors_table            IN  VARCHAR2 =: 'sys.dst$error_table');
FIND_AFFECTED_TABLES.descriptionText: This procedure finds all the tables which have affected TSTZ data due to the new timezone version. This procedure can only be invoked during a prepare window. The tables which have affected TSTZ data are recorded into a table indicated by parameter affected_tables. If semantic errors must be logged, they are recorded into a table indicated by parameter log_errors_table.

UPGRADE_DATABASE.bodyNoDefault:
num_of_failures => $1
	, upgrade_data => $2
	, parallel => $3
	, continue_after_errors => $4
	, log_errors => $5
	, log_errors_table => $6
	, error_on_overlap_time => $7
	, error_on_nonexisting_time => $8
	, log_triggers_table => $9
UPGRADE_DATABASE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_DST.UPGRADE_DATABASE  (
   num_of_failures             OUT BINARY_INTEGER,
   upgrade_data                IN  BOOLEAN := TRUE,
   parallel                    IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE,
   continue_after_errors       IN  BOOLEAN := TRUE,
   log_errors                  IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE,
   log_errors_table            IN  VARCHAR2 =: 'sys.dst$error_table' ,
   error_on_overlap_time       IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE,
   error_on_nonexisting_time   IN  BOOLEAN := FALSE,
   log_triggers_table          IN  VARCHAR2 := 'sys.dst$trigger_table');
UPGRADE_DATABASE.descriptionText: This procedure upgrades all tables in the database, which have one or more columns defined on the TSTZ type or an ADT containing the TSTZ type. This procedure can only be invoked after an upgrade window has been started. Each table is upgraded in an atomic transaction. Note that, a base table and its materialized view log table are upgraded in an atomic transaction.

	, error_on_nonexisting_time => $9

UPGRADE_SCHEMA.descriptionText: This procedure upgrades tables in a specified list of schemas that have one or more columns defined on the TSTZ type, or an ADT containing the TSTZ type. This procedure can be invoked only after an upgrade window has been started. Each table is upgraded in an atomic transaction. Note that a base table and its materialized view log table are upgraded in an atomic transaction.

SET_EDITIONING_VIEWS_READ_ONLY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_EDITIONS_UTILITIES.SET_EDITIONING_VIEWS_READ_ONLY (
   table_name IN VARCHAR2,
   owner      IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   read_only  IN BOOLEAN  DEFAULT TRUE);
SET_EDITIONING_VIEWS_READ_ONLY.descriptionText: Given the schema name and table name, this procedure sets the corresponding editioning views in all editions to READ ONLY or READ/WRITE.

SET_NULL_COLUMN_VALUES_TO_EXPR.descriptionText: This procedure replaces NULL values in a replacement column with the value of an expression. The expression evaluation cost is deferred to future updates and queries. The procedure is intended for use only during an edition-based redefinition (EBR) exercise.

AUTHORIZE_DAD.descriptionText: This procedure authorizes a DAD to invoke procedures and access document tables with a database use\'s privileges. The invoker can always authorize the use of her/his own privileges.

CREATE_DAD.descriptionText: This procedure creates a new DAD.

DEAUTHORIZE_DAD.descriptionText: This procedure deauthorizes a DAD with regard to invoking procedures and accessing document tables with a database use\'s privileges. The invoker can always deauthorize the use of his own privileges.

DELETE_DAD_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a DAD attribute.

DELETE_GLOBAL_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a global attribute.

DROP_DAD.descriptionText: This procedure drops a DAD. All the virtual-path mappings of the DAD will be dropped also

GET_ALL_DAD_ATTRIBUTES.bodyFullText:
DBMS_EPG.GET_ALL_DAD_ATTRIBUTES (
   dad_name      IN          VARCHAR2,
   attr_names    OUT NOCOPY  VARCHAR2_TABLE,                       
   attr_values   OUT NOCOPY  VARCHAR2_TABLE);
GET_ALL_DAD_ATTRIBUTES.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves all the attributes of a DAD. The outputs are 2 correlated index-by tables of the name/value pairs.

GET_ALL_DAD_MAPPINGS.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves all virtual paths to which the specified DAD is mapped.

GET_ALL_GLOBAL_ATTRIBUTES.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves all global attributes and values. The outputs are 2 correlated index-by tables of the name/value pairs.

GET_DAD_ATTRIBUTE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_EPG.GET_DAD_ATTRIBUTE (
   dad_name     IN  VARCHAR2,
   attr_name    IN  VARCHAR2)
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
GET_DAD_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value of a DAD attribute.

GET_DAD_LIST.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves a list of all DADs for an Embedded Gateway instance.

GET_GLOBAL_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This function retrieves the value of a global attribute.

MAP_DAD.descriptionText: This procedure maps a DAD to the specified virtual path. If the virtual path exists already, the old virtual-path mapping will be overridden.

SET_DAD_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure sets the value for a DAD.

SET_GLOBAL_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure sets the value of a global attribute.

UNMAP_DAD.descriptionText: This procedure unmaps a DAD from the specified virtual path. If path is NULL, the procedure removes all virtual-path mappings for the DAD but keeps the DAD.

CREATE_ERROR_LOG.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ERRLOG.CREATE_ERROR_LOG (
   dml_table_name            IN VARCHAR2,
   err_log_table_name        IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   err_log_table_owner       IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   err_log_table_space       IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   skip_unsupported          IN BOOLEAN := FALSE);
CREATE_ERROR_LOG.descriptionText: This procedure creates the error logging table needed to use the DML error logging capability.

PURGE_FILE_GROUP.descriptionText: This procedure purges a file group using the file grou\'s retention policy.

  object_name  IN  VARCHAR2,
  privilege    IN  BINARY_INTEGER,

REVOKE_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure revokes system privileges for file group operations from a user.

COPY_FILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER.COPY_FILE(
   source_directory_object       IN  VARCHAR2,
   source_file_name              IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_directory_object  IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_file_name         IN  VARCHAR2);
COPY_FILE.descriptionText: This procedure reads a file from a source directory and creates a copy of it in a destination directory. The source and destination directories can both be in a local file system, or both be in an Automatic Storage Management (ASM) disk group, or between local file system and ASM with copying in either direction.

GET_FILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER.GET_FILE
   source_directory_object      IN  VARCHAR2,    
   source_file_name             IN  VARCHAR2,  
   source_database              IN  VARCHAR2,  
   destination_directory_object IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_file_name        IN  VARCHAR2);
GET_FILE.descriptionText: This procedure contacts a remote database to read a remote file and then creates a copy of the file in the local file system or ASM. The file that is copied is the source file, and the new file that results from the copy is the destination file. The destination file is not closed until the procedure completes successfully.

PUT_FILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_FILE_TRANSFER.PUT_FILE(
   source_directory_object       IN  VARCHAR2,   
   source_file_name              IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_directory_object  IN  VARCHAR2,
   destination_file_name         IN  VARCHAR2,  
   destination_database          IN  VARCHAR2);
PUT_FILE.descriptionText: This procedure reads a local file or ASM and contacts a remote database to create a copy of the file in the remote file system. The file that is copied is the source file, and the new file that results from the copy is the destination file. The destination file is not closed until the procedure completes successfully.

DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure disables the Flashback mode for the entire session.

ENABLE_AT_SYSTEM_CHANGE_NUMBER.descriptionText: This procedure takes an SCN as an input parameter and sets the session snapshot to the specified number. In the Flashback mode, all queries return data consistent as of the specified wall-clock time or SCN. It enables Flashback for the entire session.

ENABLE_AT_TIME.descriptionText: This procedure enables Flashback for the entire session. The snapshot time is set to the SCN that most closely matches the time specified in query_time.It enables Flashback for the entire session.

GET_SYSTEM_CHANGE_NUMBER.descriptionText: This function returns the current SCN as an Oracle number datatype. You can obtain the current change number and store it for later use. This helps you retain specific snapshots.

TRANSACTION_BACKOUT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns            NUMBER,
   xids               XID_ARRAY,
   options            NUMBER default NOCASCADE, 
   timeHint           TIMESTAMP default MINTIME);

DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns            NUMBER,  
   xids               XID_ARRAY, 
   options            NUMBER default NOCASCADE,
   scnHint            TIMESTAMP default 0   );

DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns           NUMBER,
   txnnames          TXNAME_ARRAY,
   options           NUMBER default NOCASCADE,
   timehint          TIMESTAMP MINTIME );

DBMS_FLASHBACK.TRANSACTION_BACKOUT
   numtxns           NUMBER, 
   txnNames         TXNAME_ARRAY, 
   options          NUMBER default NOCASCADE,
   scnHint          NUMBER 0);
TRANSACTION_BACKOUT.descriptionText: This procedure provides a mechanism to back out a set of transactions. The user can call these procedures with either transaction names or transaction identifiers (XIDS).

ADD_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.ADD_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2,
   table_name                 IN   VARCHAR2,
   schema_name                IN   VARCHAR2 := NULL);
ADD_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION.descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and adds a table to the application as a security table. If the application is enabled for Flashback Data Archive, then this table will also be enabled for Flashback Data Archive.

CREATE_TEMP_HISTORY_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a table called TEMP_HISTORY with the correct definition in schema.

DISABLE_APPLICATION.descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and disables Flashback Data Archive on all of its security tables.

DISABLE_ASOF_VALID_TIME.descriptionText: This procedure disables session level valid-time flashback.

DISASSOCIATE_FBA.descriptionText: This procedure disassociates the given table from the flashback data archive.

DROP_APPLICATION.descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and removes it from the list of applications. As part of this procedure, Flashback Data Archive will be disabled on all security-enabled tables and all history data will be lost. The group called SYSTEM cannot be dropped.

ENABLE_APPLICATION.descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and enables Flashback Data Archive on all the security tables for this application. Once an application is enabled, every change to an FDA enabled table will be tracked.

ENABLE_AT_VALID_TIME.descriptionText: This procedure enables session level valid time flashback.

EXTEND_MAPPINGS.descriptionText: This procedure extends time mappings to times in the past.

GET_SYS_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This function gets the context previously selected by the SET_CONTEXT_LEVEL Procedure.

IMPORT_HISTORY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.IMPORT_HISTORY (
   owner_name1         IN   VARCHAR2, 
   table_name1         IN   VARCHAR2 
   temp_history_name   IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'TEMP_HISTORY',
   options             IN   BINARY_INTEGER DEFAULT 0);
IMPORT_HISTORY.descriptionText: This procedure is called after invoking the CREATE_TEMP_HISTORY_TABLE Procedure procedure, and after the TEMP_HISTORY table is populated with user-generated history data.

LOCK_DOWN_APPLICATION.descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and makes all the security tables read-only. The group called SYSTEM cannot be locked.

PURGE_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure purges the context to be saved selected by the SET_CONTEXT_LEVEL Procedure.

REASSOCIATE_FBA.descriptionText: This procedure reassociates the given table with the flashback data archive.

REGISTER_APPLICATION.descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and optionally a Flashback Data Archive, and registers an application for database hardening. When database hardening is enabled, then all the security tables for that application are enabled for Flashback Data Archive using the given Flashback Data Archive. If no Flashback Data Archive is specified, the default Flashback Data Archive is used.

REMOVE_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_FLASHBACK_ARCHIVE.REMOVE_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION (
   application_name           IN   VARCHAR2,
   table_name                 IN   VARCHAR2,
   schema_name                IN   VARCHAR2 := NULL);
REMOVE_TABLE_TO_APPLICATION.descriptionText: This procedure takes an application name and marks a table in it as no longer being a security table. If the application is already enabled for Flashback Data Archive, Flashback Data Archive will be disabled for this table.

SET_CONTEXT_LEVEL.descriptionText: This procedure defines how much of the user context is to be saved.

     support        NUMBER,

FI_HORIZONTAL.descriptionText: The purpose of this table function is to count all frequent itemsets given a cursor for input data which is in\'HORIZONTA\' row format, support threshold, minimum itemset length, maximum itemset length, items to be included, items to be excluded. The result will be a table of rows in form of itemset, support, length, total transactions counted.

tranx_cursor => $1
	, support_threshold => $2

	, excluding_items => $6

DBMS_FREQUENT_ITEMSET.FI_TRANSACTIONAL (

   excluding_items      IN    SYS_REFCURSOR DEFAULT NULL)
  RETURN TABLE OF ROW (
     itemset [Nested Table of Item Type DERIVED FROM tranx_cursor],
     support        NUMBER,
     length         NUMBER,
     total_tranx    NUMBER);
FI_TRANSACTIONAL.descriptionText: This procedure counts all frequent itemsets given a cursor for input data which is in\'TRANSACTIONA\' row format, support threshold, minimum itemset length, maximum itemset length, items to be included, items to be excluded. The result will be a table of rows in form of itemset, support, length, total number of transactions.

BLOCK_HEAT_MAP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_HEAT_MAP.BLOCK_HEAT_MAP (
   owner             IN VARCHAR2,
   segment_name      IN VARCHAR2,
   partition_name    IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   sort_columnid     IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL,
   sort_order        IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL) 
RETURN hm_bls_row PIPELINED;
BLOCK_HEAT_MAP.descriptionText: This table function returns the last modification time for each block in a table segment. It returns no information for segment types that are not data.

EXTENT_HEAT_MAP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_HEAT_MAP.EXTENT_HEAT_MAP (
   owner             IN VARCHAR2,
   segment_name      IN VARCHAR2,
   partition_name    IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
RETURN hm_els_row PIPELINED;
EXTENT_HEAT_MAP.descriptionText: This table function returns the extent level Heat Map statistics for a table segment. It returns no information for segment types that are not data. Aggregates at extent level, including minimum modification time and maximum modification time, are included.

OBJECT_HEAT_MAP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_HEAT_MAP.OBJECT_HEAT_MAP (
   object_owner      IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name       IN VARCHAR2) 
 RETURN hm_object_table PIPELINED;
OBJECT_HEAT_MAP.descriptionText: This table function returns the minimum, maximum and average access times for all the segments belonging to the object. The object must be a table. The table function raises an error if called on object tables other than table.

    type           IN  VARCHAR2 := 'TEXT',
    level          IN  VARCHAR2 := 'BASIC',) 
  RETURN CLOB;
GET_RUN_REPORT.descriptionText: This function returns the report for the specified checker run.

RUN_CHECK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_HM.RUN_CHECK (
   check_name     IN  VARCHAR2,
   run_name       IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,

   input_params   IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL);

START_PROFILING.bodyFullText:
DBMS_HPROF.START_PROFILING (
   location    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   filename    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   max_depth   PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT NULL);
START_PROFILING.descriptionText: This procedure starts hierarchical profiler data collection in the use\'s session.

STOP_PROFILING.descriptionText: This procedure stops profiler data collection in the use\'s session. This subprogram also has the side effect of flushing data collected so far in the session, and it signals the end of a run.

ADD_TO_ILM.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM.ADD_TO_ILM (
   task_id           IN    NUMBER,
   owner             IN    VARCHAR2,
   object_name       IN    VARCHAR2,
   subobject_name    IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
ADD_TO_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure adds the object specified through the argument to a particular ADO task and evaluates the ADO policies on this object. The procedure can only be executed on an ADO task in an inactive state. The results of the ADO policy evaluation on this object can be viewed using the appropriate views depending on role and access (USER_ILMTASKS or DBA_ILMTASKS, USER_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS or DBA_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS, USER_ILMRESULTS or DBA_ILMRESULTS).

ARCHIVESTATENAME.descriptionText: This function returns the value of the ORA_ARCHIVE_STATE column of a row-archival enabled table.

EXECUTE_ILM.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM.EXECUTE_ILM (
   task_id             OUT    NUMBER,
   ilm_scope           IN     NUMBER DEFAULT SCOPE_SCHEMA,
   execution_mode      IN     NUMBER DEFAULT ILM_EXECUTION_ONLINE);

DBMS_ILM.EXECUTE_ILM (
   owner               IN     VARCHAR2,
   object_name         IN     VARCHAR2,
   task_id             OUT    NUMBER, 
   subobject_name      IN     VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   policy_name         IN     VARCHAR2 DEFAULT ILM_ALL_POLICIES,
   execution_mode      IN     NUMBER DEFAULT ILM_EXECUTION_ONLINE);
EXECUTE_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure executes an ADO task.

EXECUTE_ILM_TASK.descriptionText: This procedure executes an ADO task that has been evaluated previously and moves it to an active state.

PREVIEW_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure evaluates the ADO policies on the objects specified using the ILM_SCOPE argument. It returns a number as task_id which identifies a particular ADO task. This can be used to view the results of the policy evaluation in the appropriate views depending on role and access (USER_ILMTASKS or DBA_ILMTASKS, USER_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS or DBA_ILMEVALUATIONDETAILS, USER_ILMRESULTS or DBA_ILMRESULTS).

REMOVE_FROM_ILM.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM.REMOVE_FROM_ILM (
   task_id           IN    NUMBER,
   owner             IN    VARCHAR2,
   object_name       IN    VARCHAR2,
   subobject_name    IN    VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
REMOVE_FROM_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure removes the object specified through the argument from a particular ADO task. The procedure can only be executed on an ADO task in an inactive state.

STOP_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure stops ADO-related jobs created for a particular ADO task.

CLEAR_HEAT_MAP_ALL.descriptionText: This procedure deletes all rows in HEAT_MAP_STAT$ except the dummy row.

CLEAR_HEAT_MAP_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM_ADMIN.CLEAR_HEAT_MAP_TABLE  (
   owner                   IN  VARCHAR2,
   tablename               IN  VARCHAR2,
   partition               IN  VARCHAR2 default '',
   access_date             IN  DATE DEFAULT NULL,
   segment_access_summary  IN  NUMBER DEFAULT NULL);
CLEAR_HEAT_MAP_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure clears all or some statistics for the heat map table, deleting rows for a given table or segment which match a given pattern, or all such rows.

CUSTOMIZE_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure customizes environment for ILM execution by specifying the values for ILM execution related parameters. These values take effect for the next background scheduling.

DISABLE_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure turns off all background ILM scheduling.

ENABLE_ILM.descriptionText: This procedure turns on all background ILM scheduling.

SET_HEAT_MAP_ALL.descriptionText: This procedure updates or inserts heat map rows for all tables.

SET_HEAT_MAP_START.descriptionText: This procedure sets the start date for collecting heat map data.

SET_HEAT_MAP_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ILM_ADMIN.SET_HEAT_MAP_TABLE  (
   owner                  IN VARCHAR2,
   tablename              IN VARCHAR2,
   partition              IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT '',
   access_date            IN DATE DEFAULT NULL,
   segment_access_summary IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL);
SET_HEAT_MAP_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure updates or inserts a row for the specified table or segment.

You can use this interface with any combination of persistent or temporary LOB instances as the source or destination.

   dest_lob       IN OUT NOCOPY  CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,

CONVERTTOCLOB.descriptionText: This procedure takes a source BLOB instance, converts the binary data in the source instance to character data using the character set you specify, writes the character data to a destination CLOB or NCLOB instance, and returns the new offsets. You can use this interface with any combination of persistent or temporary LOB instances as the source or destination.

COPY_DBFS_LINK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.COPY_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc_dst    IN OUT BLOB,

  flags          IN     PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE);

  lob_loc_dst    IN OUT CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,

  flags          IN     PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE);
COPY_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This procedure copies the DBFS Link in the source LOB to the destination LOB.

COPY_FROM_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the archived SecureFiles LOB data from the DBFS HSM store and to the database.

CREATETEMPORARY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.CREATETEMPORARY (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   cache   IN            BOOLEAN,
   dur     IN            PLS_INTEGER := DBMS_LOB.SESSION);
  
DBMS_LOB.CREATETEMPORARY (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   cache   IN            BOOLEAN,
   dur     IN            PLS_INTEGER := 10);
CREATETEMPORARY.descriptionText: This procedure creates a temporary BLOB or CLOB and its corresponding index in your default temporary tablespace.

DBFS_LINK_GENERATE_PATH.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.DBFS_LINK_GENERATE_PATH (
  lob_loc       IN BLOB,
  storage_dir   IN VARCHAR2) 
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
 
DBMS_LOB.DBFS_LINK_GENERATE_PATH (
  lob_loc       IN CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_dir   IN VARCHAR2) 
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
DBFS_LINK_GENERATE_PATH.descriptionText: This subprogram returns a unique file path name for use in creating a DBFS Link.

DBMS_LOB.descriptionText: This function returns TRUE if the LOB locator passed to it is for a SecureFile LOB. It returns FALSE otherwise.

ERASE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.ERASE (
   lob_loc           IN OUT   NOCOPY   BLOB,
   amount            IN OUT   NOCOPY   INTEGER,
   offset            IN                INTEGER := 1);

DBMS_LOB.ERASE (
   lob_loc           IN OUT   NOCOPY   CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount            IN OUT   NOCOPY   INTEGER,
   offset            IN                INTEGER := 1);
ERASE.descriptionText: This procedure erases an entire internal LOB or part of an internal LOB.

FILECLOSE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FILECLOSE (
    file_loc IN OUT NOCOPY BFILE);
FILECLOSE.descriptionText: This procedure closes a BFILE that has already been opened through the input locator.

FILECLOSEALL.descriptionText: This procedure closes all BFILEs opened in the session.

FILEEXISTS.descriptionText: This function finds out if a specified BFILE locator points to a file that actually exists on the serve\'s file system.

FILEGETNAME.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FILEGETNAME (
   file_loc   IN    BFILE, 
   dir_alias  OUT   VARCHAR2,
   filename   OUT   VARCHAR2);
FILEGETNAME.descriptionText: This procedure determines the directory object and filename, given a BFILE locator. This function only indicates the directory object name and filename assigned to the locator, not if the physical file or directory actually exists.

FILEISOPEN.descriptionText: This function finds out whether a BFILE was opened with the specified FILE locator.

FILEOPEN.descriptionText: This procedure opens a BFILE for read-only access. BFILE data may not be written through the database.

FRAGMENT_DELETE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_DELETE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_DELETE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER);
FRAGMENT_DELETE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes the data at the specified offset for the specified length from the LOB without having to rewrite all the data in the LOB following the specified offset.

FRAGMENT_INSERT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_INSERT (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER,
   buffer      IN            RAW);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_INSERT (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount      IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER,
   buffer      IN            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
FRAGMENT_INSERT.descriptionText: This procedure inserts the specified data (limited to 32K) into the LOB at the specified offset.

FRAGMENT_MOVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_MOVE (
   lob_loc       IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   amount        IN            INTEGER,
   src_offset    IN            INTEGER,
   dest_offset   IN            INTEGER);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_MOVE (
   lob_loc       IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount        IN            INTEGER,
   src_offset    IN            INTEGER,
   dest_offset   IN            INTEGER);
FRAGMENT_MOVE.descriptionText: This procedure moves the amount of bytes (BLOB) or characters (CLOB/NCLOB) from the specified offset to the new offset specified.

FRAGMENT_REPLACE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_REPLACE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB,
   old_amount  IN            INTEGER,
   new_amount  IN            INTEGER,
   offset      IN            INTEGER,
   buffer      IN            RAW);

DBMS_LOB.FRAGMENT_REPLACE (
   lob_loc     IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,   old_amount  IN           INTEGER,
   new_amount  IN           INTEGER,
   offset      IN           INTEGER,
   buffer      IN           VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
FRAGMENT_REPLACE.descriptionText: This procedure replaces the data at the specified offset with the specified data (not to exceed 32k).

FREETEMPORARY.descriptionText: This procedure frees the temporary BLOB or CLOB in the default temporary tablespace.

GET_DBFS_LINK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
  storage_path        OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  lob_length          OUT NUMBER);

DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_path        OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  lob_length          OUT NUMBER);
GET_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This function returns the DBFS path name for the specified SecureFile LOB.

GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE (
  lob_loc       IN BLOB,
  storage_path  OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  state         OUT NUMBER,
  cached        OUT BOOLEAN);

DBMS_LOB.GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE (
  lob_loc       IN CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  storage_path  OUT VARCHAR2(DBFS_LINK_PATH_MAX_SIZE),
  state         OUT NUMBER,
  cached        OUT BOOLEAN);
GET_DBFS_LINK_STATE.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the current link state of the specified SecureFile.

GET_STORAGE_LIMIT.descriptionText: This function returns the LOB storage limit for the specified LOB.

GETCHUNKSIZE.descriptionText: When creating the table, you can specify the chunking factor, a multiple of tablespace blocks in bytes. This corresponds to the chunk size used by the LOB data layer when accessing or modifying the LOB value. Part of the chunk is used to store system-related information, and the rest stores the LOB value.

GETCONTENTTYPE.descriptionText: This procedure returns the content type string previously set by means of the SETCONTENTTYPE Procedure.

GETLENGTH.descriptionText: This function gets the length of the specified LOB. The length in bytes or characters is returned.

GETOPTIONS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GETOPTIONS (
   lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
   option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER) 
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
 
DBMS_LOB.GETOPTIONS (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER) 
RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
GETOPTIONS.descriptionText: This function obtains compression, deduplication, and encryption settings corresponding to the option_type field for a particular LOB.

INSTR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   lob_loc    IN   BLOB,
   pattern    IN   RAW,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   lob_loc    IN   CLOB      CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   pattern    IN   VARCHAR2  CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_LOB.INSTR (
   file_loc   IN   BFILE,
   pattern    IN   RAW,
   offset     IN   INTEGER := 1,
   nth        IN   INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN INTEGER;
INSTR.descriptionText: This function returns the matching position of the nth occurrence of the pattern in the LOB, starting from the offset you specify.

ISOPEN.descriptionText: This function checks to see if the LOB was already opened using the input locator. This subprogram is for internal and external LOBs.

ISTEMPORARY.descriptionText: This function determines whether a LOB instance is temporary.

LOADBLOBFROMFILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.LOADBLOBFROMFILE (
   dest_lob    IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB, 
   src_bfile   IN            BFILE, 
   amount      IN            INTEGER, 
   dest_offset IN OUT        INTEGER, 
   src_offset  IN OUT        INTEGER);
LOADBLOBFROMFILE.descriptionText: This procedure loads data from BFILE to internal BLOB. This achieves the same outcome as LOADFROMFILE, and returns the new offsets.

LOADCLOBFROMFILE.bodyNoDefault:
dest_lob => $1
	, src_bfile => $2
	, amount => $3
	, dest_offset => $4
	, src_offset => $5
	, bfile_csid => $6
	, lang_context => $7
	, warning => $8
LOADCLOBFROMFILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.LOADCLOBFROMFILE (
   dest_lob       IN OUT NOCOPY   NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS, 
   src_bfile      IN              BFILE, 
   amount         IN              INTEGER, 
   dest_offset    IN OUT          INTEGER, 
   src_offset     IN OUT          INTEGER,
   bfile_csid     IN              NUMBER,
   lang_context   IN OUT          INTEGER,
   warning        OUT             INTEGER);
LOADCLOBFROMFILE.descriptionText: This procedure loads data from a BFILE to an internal CLOB/NCLOB with necessary character set conversion and returns the new offsets.

LOADFROMFILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.LOADFROMFILE (
   dest_lob    IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB, 
   src_file    IN            BFILE, 
   amount      IN            INTEGER, 
   dest_offset IN            INTEGER  := 1, 
   src_offset  IN            INTEGER  := 1);
LOADFROMFILE.descriptionText: This procedure copies all, or a part of, a source external LOB (BFILE) to a destination internal LOB.

MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK (
  lob_loc       IN OUT BLOB,
  storage_path  IN     VARCHAR2(dbfs_link_path_max_size),

DBMS_LOB.MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK (

  flags         IN     BINARY INTEGER DEFAULT DBFS_LINK_NOCACHE);
MOVE_TO_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This procedure archives the specified LOB data (from the database) into the DBFS HSM Store.

OPEN.descriptionText: This procedure opens a LOB, internal or external, in the indicated mode. Valid modes include read-only, and read/write.

READ.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.READ (
   lob_loc   IN             BLOB,
   amount    IN OUT  NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN             INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT            RAW);

DBMS_LOB.READ (
   lob_loc   IN             CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount    IN OUT  NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN             INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET); 

DBMS_LOB.READ (
   file_loc   IN             BFILE,
   amount    IN OUT   NOCOPY INTEGER,
   offset    IN              INTEGER,
   buffer    OUT             RAW);
READ.descriptionText: This procedure reads a piece of a LOB, and returns the specified amount into the buffer parameter, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB.

SET_DBFS_LINK.descriptionText: This function links the specified SecureFile to the specified path name. It does not copy the data to the path.

SETCONTENTTYPE.descriptionText: This procedure sets the content type string for the data in the LOB.

SETOPTIONS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.SETOPTIONS (
   lob_loc             IN     BLOB,
   option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER,
   options             IN     PLS_INTEGER);
 
DBMS_LOB.SETOPTIONS (
  lob_loc             IN     CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
  option_types        IN     PLS_INTEGER, 
  options             IN     PLS_INTEGER);
SETOPTIONS.descriptionText: This procedure enables/disables compression and deduplication on a per-LOB basis, overriding the default LOB column settings.

SUBSTR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   lob_loc     IN    BLOB,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN RAW;

DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   lob_loc     IN    CLOB   CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET;

DBMS_LOB.SUBSTR (
   file_loc     IN    BFILE,
   amount      IN    INTEGER := 32767,
   offset      IN    INTEGER := 1)
  RETURN RAW;
SUBSTR.descriptionText: This function returns amount bytes or characters of a LOB, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB.

TRIM.descriptionText: This procedure trims the value of the internal LOB to the length you specify in the newlen parameter. Specify the length in bytes for BLOBs, and specify the length in characters for CLOBs.

WRITE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.WRITE (
   lob_loc  IN OUT NOCOPY  BLOB,
   amount   IN             INTEGER,
   offset   IN             INTEGER,
   buffer   IN             RAW);

DBMS_LOB.WRITE (
   lob_loc  IN OUT  NOCOPY CLOB   CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   amount   IN             INTEGER,
   offset   IN             INTEGER,
   buffer   IN             VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
WRITE.descriptionText: This procedure writes a specified amount of data into an internal LOB, starting from an absolute offset from the beginning of the LOB. The data is written from the buffer parameter.

WRITEAPPEND.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.WRITEAPPEND (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY BLOB, 
   amount  IN            INTEGER, 
   buffer  IN            RAW); 

DBMS_LOB.WRITEAPPEND (
   lob_loc IN OUT NOCOPY CLOB CHARACTER SET ANY_CS, 
   amount  IN            INTEGER, 
   buffer  IN            VARCHAR2 CHARACTER SET lob_loc%CHARSET);
WRITEAPPEND.descriptionText: This procedure writes a specified amount of data to the end of an internal LOB. The data is written from the buffer parameter.

UNSUBSCRIBE_USER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.UNSUBSCRIBE_USER(
        LD IN RAW 
        USER_HANDLE IN RAW 
        SERVICE_HANDLE IN RAW 
)
return BINARY_INTEGER

GET_DEDUPLICATE_REGIONS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOB.GET_DEDUPLICATE_REGIONS(
        LOB_LOC IN BLOB 
        REGION_TABLE IN/OUT PL/SQL TABLE 
)

ALLOCATE_UNIQUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.ALLOCATE_UNIQUE (
   lockname         IN  VARCHAR2,
   lockhandle       OUT VARCHAR2,
   expiration_secs  IN  INTEGER   DEFAULT 864000);
ALLOCATE_UNIQUE.descriptionText: This procedure allocates a unique lock identifier (in the range of 1073741824 to 1999999999) a specified lock name. Lock identifiers are used to enable applications to coordinate their use of locks. This is provided because it may be easier for applications to coordinate their use of locks based on lock names rather than lock numbers.

CONVERT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.CONVERT(
   id         IN INTEGER || 
   lockhandle IN VARCHAR2,
   lockmode   IN INTEGER,
   timeout    IN NUMBER DEFAULT MAXWAIT)
  RETURN INTEGER;
CONVERT.descriptionText: This function converts a lock from one mode to another. CONVERT is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

RELEASE.descriptionText: This function explicitly releases a lock previously acquired using the REQUEST function. Locks are automatically released at the end of a session. RELEASE is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

REQUEST.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOCK.REQUEST(
   id                 IN  INTEGER ||
   lockhandle         IN  VARCHAR2,
   lockmode           IN  INTEGER DEFAULT X_MODE,
   timeout            IN  INTEGER DEFAULT MAXWAIT,
   release_on_commit  IN  BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE)
  RETURN INTEGER;
REQUEST.descriptionText: This function requests a lock with a specified mode. REQUEST is an overloaded function that accepts either a user-defined lock identifier, or the lock handle returned by the ALLOCATE_UNIQUE procedure.

SLEEP.descriptionText: This procedure suspends the session for a specified period of time.

ADD_LOGFILE.descriptionText: This procedure adds a file to an existing or newly created list of log files for LogMiner to process.

COLUMN_PRESENT.descriptionText: This function is designed to be used in conjunction with the MINE_VALUE function.

END_LOGMNR.descriptionText: This procedure finishes a LogMiner session. Because this procedure performs cleanup operations that may not otherwise be done, you must use it to properly end a LogMiner session. This procedure is called automatically when you log out of a database session or when you call DBMS_LOGMNR.ADD_LOGFILE and specify the NEW option.

MINE_VALUE.descriptionText: This function facilitates queries based on a colum\'s data value. This function takes two arguments. The first one specifies whether to mine the redo (REDO_VALUE) or undo (UNDO_VALUE) portion of the data. The second argument is a string that specifies the fully qualified name of the column to be mined. The MINE_VALUE function always returns a string that can be converted back to the original datatype.

REMOVE_LOGFILE.descriptionText: This procedure removes a redo log file from an existing list of redo log files for LogMiner to process.

START_LOGMNR.bodyNoDefault:
startScn => $1
	, endScn => $2
	, startTime => $3
	, endTime => $4
	, DictFileName => $5
	, Options => $6
START_LOGMNR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR.START_LOGMNR ( 
   startScn           IN NUMBER default 0,
   endScn             IN NUMBER default 0,
   startTime          IN DATE default '01-jan-1988',
   endTime            IN DATE default '31-dec-2110',
   DictFileName       IN VARCHAR2 default '',
   Options            IN BINARY_INTEGER default 0 );
START_LOGMNR.descriptionText: This procedure starts LogMiner by loading the dictionary that LogMiner will use to translate internal schema object identifiers to names.

BUILD.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGMNR_D.BUILD (
     dictionary_filename  IN  VARCHAR2,
     dictionary_location  IN  VARCHAR2,
     options              IN  NUMBER);
BUILD.descriptionText: This procedure extracts the LogMiner data dictionary to either the redo log files or to a flat file.

SET_TABLESPACE.descriptionText: By default, all LogMiner tables are created to use the SYSAUX tablespace. However, it may be desirable to have LogMiner tables use an alternate tablespace. Use this procedure to move LogMiner tables to an alternate tablespace.

APPLY_SET.descriptionText: Use this procedure to set values of parameters that configure and manage SQL Apply in a logical standby database environment. All parameters, except for PRESERVE_COMMIT_ORDER, can be changed without having to stop SQL Apply.

APPLY_UNSET.descriptionText: Use the APPLY_UNSET procedure to restore the default values of the parameters that you changed with the APPLY_SET procedure.

BUILD.descriptionText: Use this procedure on the primary database to record relevant metadata (LogMiner dictionary) information in the redo log, which will subsequently be used by SQL Apply. This procedure will enable database-wide primary- and unique-key supplemental logging, if necessary.

EDS_ADD_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_ADD_TABLE (
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
                             p_dblink           IN VARCHAR2);
EDS_ADD_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure adds EDS-based replication for the table. It should be invoked on the primary database first and then on the standby database.

EDS_EVOLVE_AUTOMATIC.descriptionText: This procedure either enables or disables automatic DDL handling for EDS tables.

EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL (
     options            IN VARCHAR2,
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2);
EDS_EVOLVE_MANUAL.descriptionText: This procedure allows you to evolve EDS tables manually (that is, manually take compensating actions based on DDLs on the base tables with EDS-replication).

EDS_REMOVE_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.EDS_REMOVE_TABLE (
     table_owner        IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
EDS_REMOVE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure removes EDS-based replication for the specified table. It also drops the shadow table and triggers.

INSTANTIATE_TABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.INSTANTIATE_TABLE (
     schema_name         IN VARCHAR2,
     table_name          IN VARCHAR2,
     dblink              IN VARCHAR2);
INSTANTIATE_TABLE.descriptionText: This procedure creates and populates a table in the standby database from a corresponding table in the primary database. The table requires the name of the database link (dblink) as an input parameter. If the table already exists in the logical standby database, it will be dropped and re-created based on the table definition at the primary database. This procedure only brings over the data associated with the table, and not the associated indexes and constraints.

IS_APPLY_SERVER.descriptionText: This function returns TRUE if it is executed from PL/SQL in the context of a logical standby apply server process. This function is used in conjunction with triggers that have the fire_once parameter in the DBMS_DDL.SET_TRIGGER_FIRING_PROPERTY subprogram set to FALSE (the default is TRUE). Such triggers are executed when the relevant target is updated by an apply process. This function can be used within the body of the trigger to ensure that the trigger takes different (or no) actions on the primary or on the standby.

MAP_PRIMARY_SCN.descriptionText: Returns an SCN on the standby that predates the supplied SCN from the primary database by at least 5 minutes. This function can be used to determine a safe SCN to use in a compensating flashback database operation at the logical standby database, following a flashback database operation or a point-in-time recovery operation at the primary database.

PREPARE_FOR_NEW_PRIMARY.descriptionText: The PREPARE_FOR_NEW_PRIMARY procedure must be invoked at a logical standby database following a failover if that standby database was not the target of the failover operation. Such a standby database must process the exact same set of redo logs processed at the new primary database. This routine ensures that the local logical standby database has not processed more redo than the new primary database and reports the set of archive logs that must be replaced to ensure consistency. The set of replacement logs will be reported in the alert.log. These logs must be copied to the logical standby and registered using the ALTER DATABASE REGISTER LOGICAL LOGFILE statement.

PURGE_SESSION.descriptionText: Identifies all archived redo log files that have been applied to the logical standby database and are no longer needed by SQL Apply. Once identified, you can issue operating system commands to delete some or all of the unnecessary archived redo log files.

REBUILD.descriptionText: This procedure is used if a database that has recently changed its role to a primary database following a failover operation fails to record relevant metadata (including the LogMiner dictionary) in the redo stream required for other logical standby databases.

SET_TABLESPACE.descriptionText: Moves metadata tables required by SQL Apply to the user-specified tablespace. By default, the metadata tables are created in the SYSAUX tablespace. SQL Apply cannot be running when you invoke this procedure.

SKIP.bodyNoDefault:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => $2
	, object_name => $3
	, proc_name => $4
	, use_like => $5
	, esc => $6
SKIP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     proc_name                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     use_like                  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
     esc                       IN CHAR1 DEFAULT NULL);
SKIP.descriptionText: The SKIP procedure can be used to define rules that will be used by SQL Apply to skip the application of certain changes to the logical standby database. For example, the SKIP procedure can be used to skip changes to a subset of tables in the logical standby database. It can also be used to specify DDL statements that should not be applied at the logical standby database or should be modified before they are applied in the logical standby database. One reason why a DDL statement may need to be modified is to accommodate a different directory structure on the logical standby database.

SKIP_ERROR.bodyNoDefault:
stmt => $1
	, schema_name => $2
	, object_name => $3
	, proc_name => $4
	, use_like => $5
	, esc => $6
SKIP_ERROR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP_ERROR (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     proc_name                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     use_like                  IN BOOLEAN  DEFAULT NULL,
     esc                       IN CHAR1    DEFAULT NULL);
SKIP_ERROR.descriptionText: Upon encountering an error, the logical standby database uses the criteria contained in this procedure to determine a course of action. The default action when a match is found is to skip the error and continue with applying changes. However, if a procedure is supplied, then SKIP_ERROR can take other actions depending on the situation. It can do nothing, which causes SQL Apply to stop, or it can change the error message text and stop SQL Apply, or it can actually skip the error.

SKIP_TRANSACTION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.SKIP_TRANSACTION (
     xidusn          IN NUMBER,
     xidslt          IN NUMBER,
     xidsqn          IN NUMBER);
SKIP_TRANSACTION.descriptionText: This procedure provides a way to skip (ignore) applying transactions to the logical standby database. You can skip specific transactions by specifying transaction identification information.

UNSKIP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFUALT NULL,
     container_name            IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
UNSKIP.descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP procedure must match exactly for it to delete an already-specified rule.

UNSKIP_ERROR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP_ERROR (
     stmt                      IN VARCHAR2,
     schema_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     object_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
     container_name            IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
UNSKIP_ERROR.descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP_ERROR procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP_ERROR procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP_ERROR procedure must match exactly for the procedure to delete an already-specified rule.

UNSKIP_TRANSACTION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_LOGSTDBY.UNSKIP_TRANSACTION (
     xidusn_p         IN NUMBER,
     xidslt_p         IN NUMBER,
     xidsqn_p         IN NUMBER);
UNSKIP_TRANSACTION.descriptionText: Use the UNSKIP_TRANSACTION procedure to delete rules specified earlier with the SKIP_TRANSACTION procedure. The parameters specified in the UNSKIP_TRANSACTION procedure must match exactly for the procedure to delete an already-specified rule.

CLEAR_ALL_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure clears all parameters contained within namespace LSBY_APPLY_CONTEXT.

CLEAR_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure clears the specific parameter.

GET_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value for the specified parameter.

SET_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure sets the named parameter with the specified value.

ADD_TRANSFORM.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.ADD_TRANSFORM (
   handle       IN NUMBER,
   name         IN VARCHAR2,
   encoding     IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   object_type  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL)
 RETURN NUMBER;
ADD_TRANSFORM.descriptionText: This function is used for both retrieval and submission:

CLOSE.descriptionText: This procedure is used for both retrieval and submission. This procedure invalidates the handle returned by OPEN (or OPENW) and cleans up the associated state.

CONVERT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.CONVERT (
   handle   IN NUMBER,
   document IN sys.XMLType)
 RETURN sys.ku$_multi_ddls;

DBMS_METADATA.CONVERT (
  handle   IN NUMBER,
  document IN CLOB)
 RETURN sys.ku$_multi_ddls;
CONVERT.descriptionText: The CONVERT functions and procedures transform input XML documents. The CONVERT functions return creation DDL. The CONVERT procedures return either XML or DDL, depending on the specified transforms.

FETCH_XML.descriptionText: These functions and procedures return metadata for objects meeting the criteria established by OPEN, SET_FILTER, SET_COUNT, ADD_TRANSFORM, and so on. See "Usage Notes" for the variants.

GET_QUERY.descriptionText: This function returns the text of the queries that are used by FETCH_xxx. This function assists in debugging.

OPEN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.OPEN (
   object_type  IN VARCHAR2,
   version      IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'COMPATIBLE',
   model        IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'ORACLE', 
   network_link IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL)
 RETURN NUMBER;
OPEN.descriptionText: This function specifies the type of object to be retrieved, the version of its metadata, and the object model. The return value is an opaque context handle for the set of objects to be used in subsequent calls.

OPENW.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.OPENW
  (object_type  IN VARCHAR2,
  version       IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'COMPATIBLE',
  model         IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'ORACLE') 
 RETURN NUMBER;
OPENW.descriptionText: This function specifies the type of object to be submitted and the object model. The return value is an opaque context handle.

PUT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.PUT (
   handle     IN             NUMBER,
   document   IN             sys.XMLType,
   flags      IN             NUMBER,
   results    IN OUT NOCOPY  sys.ku$_SubmitResults)
  RETURN BOOLEAN;

DBMS_METADATA.PUT (
   handle     IN             NUMBER,
   document   IN             CLOB,
   flags      IN             NUMBER,
   results    IN OUT NOCOPY  sys.ku$_SubmitResults)
 RETURN BOOLEAN;
PUT.descriptionText: This function submits an XML document containing object metadata to the database to create the object.

SET_COUNT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_METADATA.SET_COUNT (
   handle           IN NUMBER,
   value            IN NUMBER,
   object_type_path IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SET_COUNT.descriptionText: This procedure specifies the maximum number of objects to be retrieved in a single FETCH_xxx call. By default, each call to FETCH_xxx returns one object. You can use the SET_COUNT procedure to override this default. If FETCH_xxx is called from a client, specifying a count value greater than 1 can result in fewer server round trips and, therefore, improved performance.

SET_FILTER.bodyFullText:

FETCH_CLOB.descriptionText: The FETCH_CLOB functions and procedures return a CLOB showing the differences between the two documents specified by ADD_DOCUMENT.

OPENC.descriptionText: This function specifies the type of objects to be compared. The return value is an opaque context handle.

EPC_TO_ORACLE_SCHEME.descriptionText: This function converts the EPCglobal tag data translation (TDT) XML to Oracle Database tag data translation XML.

 RETURN VARCHAR2;

DBMS_MGD_ID_UTL.GET_COMPONENTS (
   category_id IN VARCHAR2,
   scheme_name IN VARCHAR2)
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
GET_COMPONENTS.descriptionText: This function returns all relevant separated component names separated by semicolon (;) for the specified scheme.

GET_ENCODINGS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MGD_ID_UTL.GET_ENCODINGS (
   category_id IN VARCHAR2,
   scheme_name IN VARCHAR2)
 RETURN VARCHAR2;
GET_ENCODINGS.descriptionText: This function returns a list of semicolon (;) separated encodings (formats) for the specified scheme.

GET_JAVA_LOGGING_LEVEL.descriptionText: This function returns an integer representing the current trace logging level.

GET_PLSQL_LOGGING_LEVEL.descriptionText: This function returns an integer representing the current PL/SQL trace logging level.

GET_SCHEME_NAMES.descriptionText: This function returns a list of semicolon (;) separated scheme names for the specified category.

GET_TDT_XML.bodyFullText:
DBMS_MGD_ID_UTL.GET_TDT_XML (
   category_id  IN VARCHAR2,
   scheme_name  IN VARCHAR2)
 RETURN CLOB;
GET_TDT_XML.descriptionText: This function returns the Oracle Database tag data translation XML for the specified scheme.

GET_VALIDATOR.descriptionText: This function returns the Oracle Database tag data translation schema.

REFRESH_CATEGORY.descriptionText: This function refreshes the metadata information on the Java stack for the specified category. This function must be called before using MGD_ID functions.

REMOVE_CATEGORY.descriptionText: This procedure removes a category including all the related TDT XML. This procedure is overloaded. The different functionality of each form of syntax is presented along with the definitions.

REMOVE_PROXY.descriptionText: This procedure unsets the host and port of the proxy server.

REMOVE_SCHEME.descriptionText: This procedure removes a tag data translation scheme from a category.

SET_JAVA_LOGGING_LEVEL.descriptionText: This procedure sets the Java trace logging level.

SET_PLSQL_LOGGING_LEVEL.descriptionText: This procedure sets the PL/SQL trace logging level.

SET_PROXY.descriptionText: This procedure sets the host and port of the proxy server for Internet access. This procedure must be called if the database server accesses the Internet using a proxy server. Internet access is necessary because some rules need to look up the Object Naming Service (ONS) table to get the company prefix index.

VALIDATE_SCHEME.descriptionText: This function validates the input tag data translation XML against the Oracle Database tag data translation schema.

SET_OPTION.descriptionText: This procedure sets a Messaging Gateway configuration option. It can be used to set an agent option, a messaging link option, or a propagation job option.

SHUTDOWN.descriptionText: This procedure shuts down the Messaging Gateway agent. No propagation activity occurs until Messaging Gateway is restarted.

STARTUP.descriptionText: This procedure starts the Messaging Gateway agent. It must be called before any propagation activity can take place.

UNREGISTER_FOREIGN_QUEUE.descriptionText: This procedure removes a non-Oracle queue entity in Messaging Gateway.

UNSCHEDULE_PROPAGATION.descriptionText: This procedure removes a propagation schedule.
