   group_name      IN VARCHAR2 NULL,
   policy_name     IN VARCHAR2 NULL);
REFRESH_GROUPED_POLICY.descriptionText: This procedure reparses the SQL statements associated with a refreshed policy.

REFRESH_POLICY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RLS.REFRESH_POLICY (
   object_schema IN VARCHAR2 NULL,
   object_name   IN VARCHAR2 NULL,
   policy_name   IN VARCHAR2 NULL);
REFRESH_POLICY.descriptionText: This procedure causes all the cached statements associated with the policy to be reparsed. This guarantees that the latest change to this policy will have immediate effect after the procedure is executed.

BUILD_PLAN.descriptionText: This procedure validates plan parameters and creates or modifies a rolling operation plan. A successfully constructed plan is required in order to perform a rolling operation. This procedure must return successfully before the START_PLAN procedure can be called to start the rolling operation. Parameter changes made after a plan has been created may require calling the BUILD_PLAN procedure to modify the existing plan. The DBA_ROLLING_EVENTS view will indicate if any invocation of the SET_PARAMETER procedure requires a plan rebuild. Failure to rebuild the plan will result in an ORA-45416 error when attempting to resume the rolling operation.

DESTROY_PLAN.descriptionText: This procedure destroys any existing upgrade plan, its parameters, and all resources associated with a rolling operation.

FINISH_PLAN.descriptionText: This procedure finalizes the rolling operation. It configures the former primary (also known as the TGM) as a physical standby, and configures remaining physical standbys to recover the upgrade redo from the future primary.

INIT_PLAN.descriptionText: This procedure initializes a rolling operation plan with system-generated default values.

ROLLBACK_PLAN.descriptionText: This procedure rolls back the configuration-wide rolling operation. Once completed, all of the databases in the leading group become physical standbys of the original primary database. This procedure can only be called if the configuration has not yet gone through a switchover operation since the START_PLAN procedure was invoked.

SET_PARAMETER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROLLING.SET_PARAMETER (
   scope    IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   name     IN NUMBER,
   value    IN VARCHAR2);
SET_PARAMETER.descriptionText: This procedure modifies a rolling operation parameter.

START_PLAN.descriptionText: This procedure starts the rolling operation. This procedure must be executed on the primary database to formally start the rolling operation. When the START_PLAN procedure is complete, the LGM (identified with the future_primary parameter in the INIT_PLAN procedure) will be converted into a fully configured transient logical standby database.

SWITCHOVER.descriptionText: This procedure performs a switchover between the current primary database (also known as the TGM) and the transient logical standby database (also known as the LGM). At the successful completion of the procedure, the LGM assumes the primary role for the Data Guard configuration.

ROWID_BLOCK_NUMBER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_BLOCK_NUMBER (
   row_id      IN   ROWID,
   ts_type_in  IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'SMALLFILE')
  RETURN NUMBER;
ROWID_BLOCK_NUMBER.descriptionText: This function returns the database block number for the input ROWID.

ROWID_CREATE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_CREATE (
   rowid_type    IN NUMBER, 
   object_number IN NUMBER,
   relative_fno  IN NUMBER,
   block_number  IN NUMBER,
   row_number    IN NUMBER) 
  RETURN ROWID;
ROWID_CREATE.descriptionText: This function lets you create a ROWID, given the component parts as parameters.

ROWID_INFO.bodyNoDefault:
rowid_in => $1
	, rowid_type => $2
	, object_number => $3
	, relative_fno => $4
	, block_number => $5
	, row_number => $6
ROWID_INFO.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_INFO (
   rowid_in         IN   ROWID,
   rowid_type       OUT  NUMBER,
   object_number    OUT  NUMBER,
   relative_fno     OUT  NUMBER,
   block_number     OUT  NUMBER,
   row_number       OUT  NUMBER);
ROWID_INFO.descriptionText: This procedure returns information about a ROWID, including its type (restricted or extended), and the components of the ROWID. This is a procedure, and it cannot be used in a SQL statement.

ROWID_OBJECT.descriptionText: This function returns the data object number for an extended ROWID. The function returns zero if the input ROWID is a restricted ROWID.

ROWID_RELATIVE_FNO.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_RELATIVE_FNO (
   rowid_id      IN   ROWID,
   ts_type_in    IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'SMALLFILE')
  RETURN NUMBER;
ROWID_RELATIVE_FNO.descriptionText: This function returns the relative file number of the ROWID specified as the IN parameter. (The file number is relative to the tablespace.)

ROWID_ROW_NUMBER.descriptionText: This function extracts the row number from the ROWID IN parameter.

ROWID_TO_ABSOLUTE_FNO.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_TO_ABSOLUTE_FNO (
   row_id      IN ROWID,
   schema_name IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name IN VARCHAR2)
  RETURN NUMBER;
ROWID_TO_ABSOLUTE_FNO.descriptionText: This function extracts the absolute file number from a ROWID, where the file number is absolute for a row in a given schema and table. The schema name and the name of the schema object (such as a table name) are provided as IN parameters for this function.

ROWID_TO_EXTENDED.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_TO_EXTENDED (
   old_rowid       IN ROWID,
   schema_name     IN VARCHAR2,   
   object_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   conversion_type IN INTEGER)
  RETURN ROWID;
ROWID_TO_EXTENDED.descriptionText: This function translates a restricted ROWID that addresses a row in a schema and table that you specify to the extended ROWID format. Later, it may be removed from this package into a different place.

ROWID_TO_RESTRICTED.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_TO_RESTRICTED (
   old_rowid       IN ROWID,
   conversion_type IN INTEGER)
  RETURN ROWID;
ROWID_TO_RESTRICTED.descriptionText: This function converts an extended ROWID into restricted ROWID format.

ROWID_TYPE.descriptionText: This function returns 0 if the ROWID is a restricted ROWID, and 1 if it is extended.

ROWID_VERIFY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_ROWID.ROWID_VERIFY (
   rowid_in        IN ROWID,
   schema_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   object_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   conversion_type IN INTEGER
  RETURN NUMBER;
ROWID_VERIFY.descriptionText: This function verifies the ROWID. It returns 0 if the input restricted ROWID can be converted to extended format, given the input schema name and table name, and it returns 1 if the conversion is not possible.

CLOSE_ITERATOR.descriptionText: This procedure closes an open iterator.

EVALUATE.bodyNoDefault:
rule_set_name => $1
	, evaluation_context => $2
	, event_context => $3
	, table_values => $4
	, column_values => $5
	, variable_values => $6
	, attribute_values => $7
	, result_cache => $8
	, stop_on_first_hit => $9
	, simple_rules_only => $10
	, true_rules => $11
	, maybe_rules => $12
EVALUATE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE.EVALUATE(
   rule_set_name          IN     VARCHAR2,
   evaluation_context     IN     VARCHAR2,
   event_context          IN     SYS.RE$NV_LIST               DEFAULT NULL,
   table_values           IN     SYS.RE$TABLE_VALUE_LIST      DEFAULT NULL,
   column_values          IN     SYS.RE$COLUMN_VALUE_LIST     DEFAULT NULL,
   variable_values        IN     SYS.RE$VARIABLE_VALUE_LIST   DEFAULT NULL,
   attribute_values       IN     SYS.RE$ATTRIBUTE_VALUE_LIST  DEFAULT NULL,
   result_cache           IN     BOOLEAN                      DEFAULT FALSE,
   stop_on_first_hit      IN     BOOLEAN                      DEFAULT FALSE,
   simple_rules_only      IN     BOOLEAN                      DEFAULT FALSE,
   true_rules             OUT    SYS.RE$RULE_HIT_LIST,
   maybe_rules            OUT    SYS.RE$RULE_HIT_LIST);

DBMS_RULE.EVALUATE(
   rule_set_name          IN     VARCHAR2,
   evaluation_context     IN     VARCHAR2,
   event_context          IN     SYS.RE$NV_LIST               DEFAULT NULL,
   table_values           IN     SYS.RE$TABLE_VALUE_LIST      DEFAULT NULL,
   column_values          IN     SYS.RE$COLUMN_VALUE_LIST     DEFAULT NULL,
   variable_values        IN     SYS.RE$VARIABLE_VALUE_LIST   DEFAULT NULL,
   attribute_values       IN     SYS.RE$ATTRIBUTE_VALUE_LIST  DEFAULT NULL,
   simple_rules_only      IN     BOOLEAN                      DEFAULT FALSE,
   true_rules_iterator    OUT    BINARY_INTEGER,
   maybe_rules_iterator   OUT    BINARY_INTEGER);
EVALUATE.descriptionText: This procedure evaluates the rules in the specified rule set that use the evaluation context specified for a specified event.

EVALUATE_EXPRESSION.bodyNoDefault:
rule_expression => $1
	, table_aliases => $2
	, variable_types => $3
	, table_values => $4
	, column_values => $5
	, variable_values => $6
	, attribute_values => $7
	, cache => $8
	, result_val => $9
EVALUATE_EXPRESSION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE.EVALUATE_EXPRESSION(
   rule_expression         IN         VARCHAR2,
   table_aliases           IN         SYS.RE$TABLE_ALIAS_LIST:= NULL,
   variable_types          IN         SYS.RE$VARIABLE_TYPE_LIST:= NULL,
   table_values            IN         SYS.RE$TABLE_VALUE_LIST:= NULL,
   column_values           IN         SYS.RE$COLUMN_VALUE_LIST:=NULL,
   variable_values         IN         SYS.RE$VARIABLE_VALUE_LIST:=NULL,
   attribute_values        IN         SYS.RE$ATTRIBUTE_VALUE_LIST:=NULL,
   cache                   IN         BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   result_val              OUT        BOOLEAN);
EVALUATE_EXPRESSION.descriptionText: This procedure allows user to evaluate an expression under the logged in user in a session.

GET_NEXT_HIT.descriptionText: This function returns the next rule that evaluated to TRUE from a true rules iterator, or returns the next rule that evaluated to MAYBE from a maybe rules iterator. The function returns NULL if there are no more rules that evaluated to TRUE or MAYBE.

IS_FAST.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE.IS_FAST(
   expression            IN       VARCHAR2,
   table_aliases         IN       SYS.RE$TABLE_ALIAS_LIST:= NULL,
   variable_types        IN       SYS.RE$VARIABLE_TYPE_LIST:= NULL,
   result_val            OUT      BOOLEAN);
IS_FAST.descriptionText: Given an expression, of either rule or Independent Expression, this procedure will return TRUE if the expression can be evaluated as fast. An expression can be evaluated as fast if the engine does not need to run any internal SQL and does not need to go to PL/SQL layer in case there are any PL/SQL functions referred.

ADD_RULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.ADD_RULE(
   rule_name           IN  VARCHAR2,
   rule_set_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   evaluation_context  IN  VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL,
   rule_comment        IN  VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL);
ADD_RULE.descriptionText: This procedure adds the specified rule to the specified rule set.

ALTER_EVALUATION_CONTEXT.bodyNoDefault:
evaluation_context_name => $1
	, table_aliases => $2
	, remove_table_aliases => $3
	, variable_types => $4
	, remove_variable_types => $5
	, evaluation_function => $6
	, remove_evaluation_function => $7
	, evaluation_context_comment => $8
	, remove_eval_context_comment => $9
ALTER_EVALUATION_CONTEXT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.ALTER_EVALUATION_CONTEXT(
  evaluation_context_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
  table_aliases                IN  SYS.RE$TABLE_ALIAS_LIST    DEFAULT NULL,
  remove_table_aliases         IN  BOOLEAN                    DEFAULT FALSE,
  variable_types               IN  SYS.RE$VARIABLE_TYPE_LIST  DEFAULT NULL,
  remove_variable_types        IN  BOOLEAN                    DEFAULT FALSE,
  evaluation_function          IN  VARCHAR2                   DEFAULT NULL,
  remove_evaluation_function   IN  BOOLEAN                    DEFAULT FALSE,
  evaluation_context_comment   IN  VARCHAR2                   DEFAULT NULL,
  remove_eval_context_comment  IN  BOOLEAN                    DEFAULT FALSE);
ALTER_EVALUATION_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure alters a rule evaluation context. A rule evaluation context defines external data that can be referenced in rule conditions. The external data can either exist as variables or as table data.

ALTER_RULE.bodyNoDefault:
rule_name => $1
	, condition => $2
	, evaluation_context => $3
	, remove_evaluation_context => $4
	, action_context => $5
	, remove_action_context => $6
	, rule_comment => $7
	, remove_rule_comment => $8
ALTER_RULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.ALTER_RULE(
   rule_name                  IN  VARCHAR2,
   condition                  IN  VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   evaluation_context         IN  VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   remove_evaluation_context  IN  BOOLEAN         DEFAULT FALSE,
   action_context             IN  SYS.RE$NV_LIST  DEFAULT NULL,
   remove_action_context      IN  BOOLEAN         DEFAULT FALSE,
   rule_comment               IN  VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   remove_rule_comment        IN  BOOLEAN         DEFAULT FALSE);
ALTER_RULE.descriptionText: This procedure changes one or more aspects of the specified rule.

CREATE_EVALUATION_CONTEXT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.CREATE_EVALUATION_CONTEXT(
  evaluation_context_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
  table_aliases                IN  SYS.RE$TABLE_ALIAS_LIST    DEFAULT NULL,
  variable_types               IN  SYS.RE$VARIABLE_TYPE_LIST  DEFAULT NULL,
  evaluation_function          IN  VARCHAR2                   DEFAULT NULL,
  evaluation_context_comment   IN  VARCHAR2                   DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_EVALUATION_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure creates a rule evaluation context. A rule evaluation context defines external data that can be referenced in rule conditions. The external data can either exist as variables or as table data.

CREATE_RULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.CREATE_RULE(
   rule_name           IN  VARCHAR2,
   condition           IN  VARCHAR2,
   evaluation_context  IN  VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL,
   action_context      IN  SYS.RE$NV_LIST  DEFAULT NULL,
   rule_comment        IN  VARCHAR2        DEFAULT NULL);

CREATE_RULE_SET.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.CREATE_RULE_SET(
   rule_set_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   evaluation_context  IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   rule_set_comment    IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_RULE_SET.descriptionText: This procedure creates a rule set.

DROP_EVALUATION_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure drops a rule evaluation context.

DROP_RULE_SET.descriptionText: This procedure drops a rule set.

GRANT_OBJECT_PRIVILEGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.GRANT_OBJECT_PRIVILEGE(
   privilege     IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   object_name   IN  VARCHAR2,
   grantee       IN  VARCHAR2,
   grant_option  IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);
GRANT_OBJECT_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure grants the specified object privilege on the specified object to the specified user or role. If a user owns the object, then the user automatically is granted all privileges on the object, with grant option.

GRANT_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.GRANT_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE(
   privilege     IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   grantee       IN  VARCHAR2,
   grant_option  IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);
GRANT_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure grant the specified system privilege to the specified user or role.

REMOVE_RULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.REMOVE_RULE(
   rule_name                IN  VARCHAR2,
   rule_set_name            IN  VARCHAR2,
   evaluation_context       IN  VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   all_evaluation_contexts  IN  BOOLEAN   DEFAULT FALSE);
REMOVE_RULE.descriptionText: This procedure removes the specified rule from the specified rule set.

REVOKE_OBJECT_PRIVILEGE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_RULE_ADM.REVOKE_OBJECT_PRIVILEGE(
   privilege    IN  BINARY_INTEGER,
   object_name  IN  VARCHAR2,
   revokee      IN  VARCHAR2);
REVOKE_OBJECT_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure revokes the specified object privilege on the specified object from the specified user or role.

REVOKE_SYSTEM_PRIVILEGE.descriptionText: This procedure revokes the specified system privilege from the specified user or role.

ADD_EVENT_QUEUE_SUBSCRIBER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.ADD_EVENT_QUEUE_SUBSCRIBER (
   subscriber_name         IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
ADD_EVENT_QUEUE_SUBSCRIBER.descriptionText: This procedure adds a user as a subscriber to the Scheduler event queue SYS.SCHEDULER$_EVENT_QUEUE, and grants the user permission to dequeue from this queue using the designated agent.

ADD_GROUP_MEMBER.descriptionText: This procedure adds one or more members to an existing group.

ADD_JOB_EMAIL_NOTIFICATION.bodyNoDefault:
job_name => $1
	, recipients => $2
	, sender => $3
	, subject => $4
	, body => $5
	, events => $6
	, JOB_CHAIN_STALLED => $7
	, filter_condition => $8
ADD_JOB_EMAIL_NOTIFICATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.ADD_JOB_EMAIL_NOTIFICATION (
    job_name             IN VARCHAR2,
    recipients           IN VARCHAR2,
    sender               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
    subject              IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFAULT_NOTIFICATION_SUBJECT,
    body                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFAULT_NOTIFICATION_BODY,
    events               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'JOB_FAILED,JOB_BROKEN,JOB_SCH_LIM_REACHED,
                             JOB_CHAIN_STALLED,JOB_OVER_MAX_DUR',
    filter_condition     IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
ADD_JOB_EMAIL_NOTIFICATION.descriptionText: This procedure adds e-mail notifications for a job. E-mails are then sent to the specified list of recipients whenever any of the specified job state events is raised.

ALTER_CHAIN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.ALTER_CHAIN (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   step_name               IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute               IN VARCHAR2,
   value                   IN BOOLEAN);
ALTER_CHAIN.descriptionText: This procedure alters an attribute of the specified steps of a chain. This affects all future runs of the specified steps, both in the currently running chain job and in future runs of the same chain job or other chain jobs that point to the chain.

ALTER_RUNNING_CHAIN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.ALTER_RUNNING_CHAIN (
   job_name                IN VARCHAR2,
   step_name               IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute               IN VARCHAR2,
   value                   IN {BOOLEAN|VARCHAR2});
ALTER_RUNNING_CHAIN.descriptionText: This procedure alters an attribute of the specified steps of a chain. This affects only steps of the instance of the chain for the specified running chain job.

CLOSE_WINDOW.descriptionText: This procedure closes an open window prematurely. A closed window means that it is no longer in effect. When a window is closed, the Scheduler switches the resource plan to the one that is in effect outside the window, or in the case of overlapping windows, to another window.

COPY_JOB.descriptionText: This procedure copies all attributes of an existing job to a new job. The new job is created disabled, while the state of the existing job is unaltered.

CREATE_CHAIN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_CHAIN (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   rule_set_name           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   evaluation_interval     IN INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND DEFAULT NULL,
   comments                IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_CHAIN.descriptionText: This procedure creates a new chain. The chain name can be optionally qualified with a schema name (for example, myschema.myname).

CREATE_CREDENTIAL.bodyNoDefault:
credential_name => $1
	, username => $2
	, password => $3
	, database_role => $4
	, windows_domain => $5
	, comments => $6
CREATE_CREDENTIAL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_CREDENTIAL (
   credential_name         IN VARCHAR2,
   username                IN VARCHAR2,
   password                IN VARCHAR2,
   database_role           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   windows_domain          IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   comments                IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_CREDENTIAL.descriptionText: This procedure creates a stored username/password pair. Credentials are assigned to jobs so that they can authenticate with a local or remote host operating system or a remote Oracle database.

CREATE_DATABASE_DESTINATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_DATABASE_DESTINATION (
   destination_name        IN VARCHAR2,
   agent                   IN VARCHAR2,
   tns_name                IN VARCHAR2,
   comments                IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_DATABASE_DESTINATION.descriptionText: This procedure creates a database destination. A database destination represents an Oracle database on which remote database jobs run.

CREATE_EVENT_SCHEDULE.bodyNoDefault:
schedule_name => $1
	, start_date => $2
	, event_condition => $3
	, queue_spec => $4
	, end_date => $5
	, comments => $6
CREATE_EVENT_SCHEDULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_EVENT_SCHEDULE (
   schedule_name           IN VARCHAR2,
   start_date              IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   event_condition         IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   queue_spec              IN VARCHAR2,
   end_date                IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   comments                IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_EVENT_SCHEDULE.descriptionText: This procedure creates an event schedule, which is used to start a job when a particular event is raised.

CREATE_FILE_WATCHER.bodyNoDefault:
file_watcher_name => $1
	, directory_path => $2
	, file_name => $3
	, credential_name => $4
	, destination => $5
	, min_file_size => $6
	, steady_state_duration => $7
	, comments => $8
	, enabled => $9
CREATE_FILE_WATCHER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_FILE_WATCHER (
   file_watcher_name            IN VARCHAR2,
   directory_path               IN VARCHAR2,
   file_name                    IN VARCHAR2,
   credential_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   destination                  IN VARCHAR2  DEFAULT NULL,
   min_file_size                IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT 0,
   steady_state_duration        IN INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND DEFAULT NULL,
   comments                     IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   enabled                      IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE);
CREATE_FILE_WATCHER.descriptionText: This procedure creates a file watcher, which is a Scheduler object that defines the location, name, and other properties of a file whose arrival on a system causes the Scheduler to start a job. After you create a file watcher, you reference it in an event-based job or event schedule.

CREATE_GROUP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_GROUP (
   group_name           IN VARCHAR2,
   group_type           IN VARCHAR2,
   member               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   comments             IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_GROUP.descriptionText: This procedure creates a group. Groups contain members, which you can specify when you create the group or at a later time. There are three types of groups: window groups, database destination groups, and external destination groups.

CREATE_JOB.bodyNoDefault:
job_name => $1
	, job_type => $2
	, job_action => $3
	, number_of_arguments => $4
	, start_date => $5
	, repeat_interval => $6
	, end_date => $7
	, job_class => $8
	, enabled => $9
	, auto_drop => $10
	, comments => $11
	, credential_name => $12
	, destination_name => $13
CREATE_JOB.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_JOB (
   job_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   job_type             IN VARCHAR2,
   job_action           IN VARCHAR2,
   number_of_arguments  IN PLS_INTEGER              DEFAULT 0,
   start_date           IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   repeat_interval      IN VARCHAR2                 DEFAULT NULL,
   end_date             IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   job_class            IN VARCHAR2                 DEFAULT 'DEFAULT_JOB_CLASS',
   enabled              IN BOOLEAN                  DEFAULT FALSE,
   auto_drop            IN BOOLEAN                  DEFAULT TRUE,
   comments             IN VARCHAR2                 DEFAULT NULL,
   credential_name      IN VARCHAR2                 DEFAULT NULL,
   destination_name     IN VARCHAR2                 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_JOB.descriptionText: This procedure creates a single job (regular or lightweight). If you create the job as enabled by setting the enabled attribute to TRUE, the Scheduler automatically runs the job according to its schedule. If you create the job disabled, the job does not run until you enable it with the SET_ATTRIBUTE Procedure.

CREATE_JOB_CLASS.bodyNoDefault:
job_class_name => $1
	, resource_consumer_group => $2
	, service => $3
	, logging_level => $4
	, log_history => $5
	, comments => $6
CREATE_JOB_CLASS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_JOB_CLASS (
   job_class_name            IN VARCHAR2,
   resource_consumer_group   IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   service                   IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   logging_level             IN PLS_INTEGER
                                DEFAULT DBMS_SCHEDULER.LOGGING_RUNS,
   log_history               IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT NULL,
   comments                  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_JOB_CLASS.descriptionText: This procedure creates a job class. Job classes are created in the SYS schema.

CREATE_JOBS.descriptionText: This procedure creates multiple jobs (regular and lightweight) and sets the values of their arguments in a single call.

CREATE_PROGRAM.bodyNoDefault:
program_name => $1
	, program_type => $2
	, program_action => $3
	, number_of_arguments => $4
	, enabled => $5
	, comments => $6
CREATE_PROGRAM.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_PROGRAM (
   program_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   program_type             IN VARCHAR2,
   program_action           IN VARCHAR2,
   number_of_arguments      IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT 0,
   enabled                  IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   comments                 IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);

CREATE_SCHEDULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_SCHEDULE (
   schedule_name          IN VARCHAR2,
   start_date             IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIMEZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   repeat_interval        IN VARCHAR2,
   end_date               IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIMEZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   comments               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);

CREATE_WINDOW.bodyNoDefault:
window_name => $1
	, resource_plan => $2
	, schedule_name => $3
	, duration => $4
	, window_priority => $5
	, comments => $6
CREATE_WINDOW.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.CREATE_WINDOW (
   window_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   resource_plan           IN VARCHAR2,
   schedule_name           IN VARCHAR2,
   duration                IN INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND,
   window_priority         IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'LOW',
   comments                IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
CREATE_WINDOW.descriptionText: This procedure creates a recurring time window and associates it with a resource plan. You can then use the window to schedule jobs that run under the associated resource plan. Windows are created in the SYS schema.

DEFINE_ANYDATA_ARGUMENT.bodyNoDefault:
program_name => $1
	, argument_position => $2
	, argument_name => $3
	, argument_type => $4
	, default_value => $5
	, out_argument => $6
DEFINE_ANYDATA_ARGUMENT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFINE_ANYDATA_ARGUMENT (
   program_name            IN VARCHAR2,
   argument_position       IN PLS_INTEGER,
   argument_name           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   argument_type           IN VARCHAR2,
   default_value           IN SYS.ANYDATA,
   out_argument            IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
DEFINE_ANYDATA_ARGUMENT.descriptionText: This procedure defines a name or default value for a program argument that is of a complex type and must be encapsulated within an ANYDATA object. A job that references the program can override the default value.

DEFINE_CHAIN_EVENT_STEP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFINE_CHAIN_EVENT_STEP (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   step_name               IN VARCHAR2,
   event_schedule_name     IN VARCHAR2,
   timeout                 IN INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND DEFAULT NULL);

DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFINE_CHAIN_EVENT_STEP (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   step_name               IN VARCHAR2,
   event_condition         IN VARCHAR2,
   queue_spec              IN VARCHAR2,
   timeout                 IN INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND DEFAULT NULL);
DEFINE_CHAIN_EVENT_STEP.descriptionText: This procedure adds or replaces a chain step and associates it with an event schedule or an inline event. Once started in a running chain, this step does not complete until the specified event has occurred. Every step in a chain must be defined before the chain can be enabled and used. Defining a step gives it a name and specifies what happens during the step. If a step already exists with this name, the new step replaces the old one.

DEFINE_CHAIN_RULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFINE_CHAIN_RULE (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   condition               IN VARCHAR2,
   action                  IN VARCHAR2,
   rule_name               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   comments                IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
DEFINE_CHAIN_RULE.descriptionText: This procedure adds a new rule to an existing chain, specified as a condition-action pair. The condition is expressed using either SQL or the Scheduler chain condition syntax and indicates the prerequisites for the action to occur. The action is a result of the condition being met.

DEFINE_CHAIN_STEP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFINE_CHAIN_STEP (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   step_name               IN VARCHAR2,
   program_name            IN VARCHAR2);
DEFINE_CHAIN_STEP.descriptionText: This procedure adds or replaces a chain step and associates it with a program or a nested chain. When the chain step is started, the specified program or chain is run. If a step already exists with the name supplied in the chain_name argument, the new step replaces the old one.

DEFINE_METADATA_ARGUMENT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DEFINE_METADATA_ARGUMENT (
  program_name            IN VARCHAR2,
  metadata_attribute      IN VARCHAR2,
  argument_position       IN PLS_INTEGER,
  argument_name           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
DEFINE_METADATA_ARGUMENT.descriptionText: This procedure defines a special metadata argument for the program. The Scheduler can pass Scheduler metadata through this argument to your stored procedure or other executable. You cannot set values for jobs using this argument.

DEFINE_PROGRAM_ARGUMENT.bodyFullText:
define_program_argument(
   program_name            IN VARCHAR2,
   argument_position       IN PLS_INTEGER,
   argument_name           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
   argument_type           IN VARCHAR2,
   out_argument            IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
DEFINE_PROGRAM_ARGUMENT.descriptionText: This procedure defines a name or default value for a program argument. If no default value is defined for a program argument, the job that references the program must supply an argument value. (The job can also override a default value.)

DISABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DISABLE (
   name              IN VARCHAR2,
   force             IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   commit_semantics  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'STOP_ON_FIRST_ERROR');
DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure disables a program, job, chain, window, database destination, external destination, file watcher, or group. When an object is disabled, its enabled attribute is set to FALSE.

DROP_AGENT_DESTINATION.descriptionText: This procedure drops one or more external destinations, also known as agent destinations. It should be used only when the preferred method of dropping an external destination, using the schagent utility to unregister a Scheduler agent with a database, is unavailable due to failures.

DROP_CHAIN.descriptionText: This procedure drops an existing chain.

DROP_CHAIN_RULE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DROP_CHAIN_RULE (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   rule_name               IN VARCHAR2,
   force                   IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
DROP_CHAIN_RULE.descriptionText: This procedure removes a rule from an existing chain. The rule object corresponding to this rule will also be dropped. The chain will not be disabled. If dropping this rule makes the chain invalid, the user should first disable the chain to ensure that it does not run.

DROP_CHAIN_STEP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DROP_CHAIN_STEP (
   chain_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   step_name               IN VARCHAR2,
   force                   IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
DROP_CHAIN_STEP.descriptionText: This procedure drops a chain step. If this chain step is still used in the chain rules, the chain will be disabled.

DROP_DATABASE_DESTINATION.descriptionText: This procedure drops one or more database destinations.

DROP_FILE_WATCHER.descriptionText: This procedure drops one or more file watchers.

DROP_GROUP.descriptionText: This procedure drops one or more groups.

DROP_JOB.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.DROP_JOB (
   job_name                IN VARCHAR2,
   force                   IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   defer                   IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE,
   commit_semantics        IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'STOP_ON_FIRST_ERROR');
DROP_JOB.descriptionText: This procedure drops one or more jobs or all jobs in one or more job classes. Dropping a job also drops all argument values set for that job.

DROP_JOB_CLASS.descriptionText: This procedure drops a job class. Dropping a job class means that all the metadata about the job class is removed from the database.

DROP_PROGRAM.descriptionText: This procedure drops a program. Any arguments that pertain to the program are also dropped when the program is dropped.

DROP_PROGRAM_ARGUMENT.descriptionText: This procedure drops a program argument. An argument can be specified by either name (if one has been given) or position.

DROP_WINDOW.descriptionText: This procedure drops a window. All metadata about the window is removed from the database. The window is removed from any groups that reference it.

ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables a program, job, chain, window, database destination, external destination, file watcher, or group. When an object is enabled, its enabled attribute is set to TRUE. By default, jobs, chains, and programs are created disabled and database destinations, external destinations, file watchers, windows, and groups are created enabled.

END_DETACHED_JOB_RUN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.END_DETACHED_JOB_RUN (
   job_name          IN VARCHAR2,
   error_number      IN PLS_INTEGER DEFAULT 0,
   additional_info   IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
END_DETACHED_JOB_RUN.descriptionText: This procedure ends a detached job run. A detached job points to a detached program, which is a program with the detached attribute set to TRUE. A detached job run does not end until this procedure or the STOP_JOB Procedure is called.

EVALUATE_CALENDAR_STRING.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.EVALUATE_CALENDAR_STRING (
   calendar_string    IN  VARCHAR2,
   start_date         IN  TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE,
   return_date_after  IN  TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE,
   next_run_date      OUT TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE);
EVALUATE_CALENDAR_STRING.descriptionText: You can define repeat intervals of jobs, windows or schedules using the Scheduler calendaring syntax. This procedure evaluates the calendar expression and tells you the next execution date and time of a job or window. This is very useful for testing the correct definition of the calendar string without actually scheduling the job or window.

EVALUATE_RUNNING_CHAIN.descriptionText: This procedure forces reevaluation of the rules of a running chain to trigger any rules for which the conditions have been satisfied. The job passed as an argument must point to a chain and must be running. If the job is not running, an error is thrown. (RUN_JOB can be used to start the job.)

GENERATE_JOB_NAME.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.GENERATE_JOB_NAME (
   prefix        IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'JOB$_') RETURN VARCHAR2;
GENERATE_JOB_NAME.descriptionText: This function returns a unique name for a job. The name will be of the form {prefix}N where N is a number from a sequence. If no prefix is specified, the generated name will, by default, be JOB$_1, JOB$_2, JOB$_3, and so on. If\'SCOT\' is specified as the prefix, the name will be SCOTT1, SCOTT2, and so on.

GET_AGENT_INFO.descriptionText: This function can return job information specific to an agent, such as how many are running and so on, depending on the attribute selected.

GET_AGENT_VERSION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.GET_AGENT_VERSION (
   agent_host        IN VARCHAR2) RETURN VARCHAR2;
GET_AGENT_VERSION.descriptionText: This function returns the version string of a Scheduler agent that is registered with the database and is currently running. GET_AGENT_VERSION throws an error if the agent is not registered with the database or if the agent is not currently running.

GET_ATTRIBUTE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.GET_ATTRIBUTE (
   name           IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute      IN VARCHAR2,
   value          OUT {VARCHAR2|PLS_INTEGER|BOOLEAN|DATE|TIMESTAMP|
                        TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE|TIMESTAMP WITH LOCAL TIME ZONE|
                        INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND});

DBMS_SCHEDULER.GET_ATTRIBUTE (
   name           IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute      IN VARCHAR2,
   value          OUT VARCHAR2,
   value2         OUT VARCHAR2);
GET_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value of an attribute of a Scheduler object. It is overloaded to retrieve values of various types.

GET_FILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.GET_FILE (
   source_file                  IN VARCHAR2,
   source_host                  IN VARCHAR2,
   credential_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   file_contents                IN OUT NOCOPY {BLOB|CLOB});
DBMS_SCHEDULER.GET_FILE (
   source_file                  IN VARCHAR2,
   source_host                  IN VARCHAR2,
   credential_name              IN VARCHAR2,
   destination_file_name        IN VARCHAR2,
   destination_directory_object IN VARCHAR2,
   destination_permissions      IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
GET_FILE.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves a file from the operating system file system of a specified host. The file is copied to a destination, or its contents are returned in a procedure output parameter.

GET_SCHEDULER_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure retrieves the value of a Scheduler attribute.

OPEN_WINDOW.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.OPEN_WINDOW (
   window_name             IN VARCHAR2,
   duration                IN INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND,
   force                   IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE);
OPEN_WINDOW.descriptionText: This procedure manually opens a window, unrelated to its schedule. The window opens and the resource plan associated with it takes effect immediately, for the duration specified or for the normal duration of the window, if no duration is given. Only an enabled window can be manually opened.

PURGE_LOG.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.PURGE_LOG (
   log_history             IN PLS_INTEGER  DEFAULT 0,
   which_log               IN VARCHAR2     DEFAULT 'JOB_AND_WINDOW_LOG',
   job_name                IN VARCHAR2     DEFAULT NULL);
PURGE_LOG.descriptionText: By default, the Scheduler automatically purges all rows in the job log and window log that are older than 30 days. The PURGE_LOG procedure is used to purge additional rows from the job and window log.

PUT_FILE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.PUT_FILE (
   destination_file         IN VARCHAR2,
   destination_host         IN VARCHAR2,
   credential_name          IN VARCHAR2,
   file_contents            IN {BLOB|CLOB},
   destination_permissions  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
DBMS_SCHEDULER.PUT_FILE (
   destination_file         IN VARCHAR2,
   destination_host         IN VARCHAR2,
   credential_name          IN VARCHAR2,
   source_file_name         IN VARCHAR2,
   source_directory_object  IN VARCHAR2,
   destination_permissions  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
PUT_FILE.descriptionText: This procedure saves a file to the operating system file system of a specified remote host or of the local computer. It differs from the equivalent UTL_FILE procedure in that it uses a credential and can save files to a remote host that has only a Scheduler agent (and not an Oracle Database) installed.

REMOVE_EVENT_QUEUE_SUBSCRIBER.descriptionText: This procedure unsubscribes a user from the Scheduler event queue SYS.SCHEDULER$_EVENT_QUEUE.

REMOVE_GROUP_MEMBER.descriptionText: This procedure removes one or more members from an existing group.

REMOVE_JOB_EMAIL_NOTIFICATION.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.REMOVE_JOB_EMAIL_NOTIFICATION (
    job_name             IN VARCHAR2,
    recipients           IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL,
    events               IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
REMOVE_JOB_EMAIL_NOTIFICATION.descriptionText: This procedure removes e-mail notifications for a job. You can remove all e-mail notifications or remove notifications only for specified recipients or specified events.

REPEAT_INTERVAL.bodyFullText:
repeat_interval = regular_schedule | combined_schedule
 
regular_schedule = frequency_clause
[";" interval_clause] [";" bymonth_clause] [";" byweekno_clause]
[";" byyearday_clause] [";" bydate_clause] [";" bymonthday_clause]
[";" byday_clause] [";" byhour_clause] [";" byminute_clause]
[";" bysecond_clause] [";" bysetpos_clause] [";" include_clause]
[";" exclude_clause] [";" intersect_clause][";" periods_clause]
[";" byperiod_clause]
 
frequency_clause = "FREQ" "=" ( predefined_frequency | user_defined_frequency )
predefined_frequency = "YEARLY" | "MONTHLY" | "WEEKLY" | "DAILY" | 
   "HOURLY" | "MINUTELY" | "SECONDLY"
user_defined_frequency = named_schedule

interval_clause = "INTERVAL" "=" intervalnum
   intervalnum = 1 through 99
bymonth_clause = "BYMONTH" "=" monthlist
   monthlist = month ( "," month)*
   month = numeric_month | char_month
   numeric_month = 1 | 2 | 3 ...  12
   char_month = "JAN" | "FEB" | "MAR" | "APR" | "MAY" | "JUN" |
   "JUL" | "AUG" | "SEP" | "OCT" | "NOV" | "DEC"
byweekno_clause = "BYWEEKNO" "=" weeknumber_list
   weeknumber_list = weeknumber ( "," weeknumber)*
   weeknumber = [minus] weekno
   weekno = 1 through 53
byyearday_clause = "BYYEARDAY" "=" yearday_list
   yearday_list = yearday ( "," yearday)*
   yearday = [minus] yeardaynum
   yeardaynum = 1 through 366
bydate_clause = "BYDATE" "=" date_list
   date_list = date ( "," date)*
   date = [YYYY]MMDD [ offset | span ]
bymonthday_clause = "BYMONTHDAY" "=" monthday_list
   monthday_list = monthday ( "," monthday)*
   monthday = [minus] monthdaynum
   monthdaynum = 1 through 31
byday_clause = "BYDAY" "=" byday_list
   byday_list = byday ( "," byday)*
   byday = [weekdaynum] day
   weekdaynum = [minus] daynum
   daynum = 1 through 53 /* if frequency is yearly */
   daynum = 1 through 5  /* if frequency is monthly */
   day = "MON" | "TUE" | "WED" | "THU" | "FRI" | "SAT" | "SUN"
BYTIME clause:  BYTIME=[hour_minute_second_list|minute_second_list]
   hour_minute_second_list: hh24mmss, .., hh24mmss
   minute_second_list: mmss, .. mmss
byhour_clause = "BYHOUR" "=" hour_list
   hour_list = hour ( "," hour)*
   hour = 0 through 23
byminute_clause = "BYMINUTE" "=" minute_list
   minute_list = minute ( "," minute)*
   minute = 0 through 59
bysecond_clause = "BYSECOND" "=" second_list
   second_list = second ( "," second)*
   second = 0 through 59
bysetpos_clause = "BYSETPOS" "=" setpos_list
   setpos_list = setpos ("," setpos)*
   setpos = [minus] setpos_num
   setpos_num = 1 through 9999

include_clause = "INCLUDE" "=" schedule_list
exclude_clause = "EXCLUDE" "=" schedule_list
intersect_clause = "INTERSECT" "=" schedule_list
schedule_list = schedule_clause ("," schedule_clause)*
schedule_clause = named_schedule [ offset ]
named_schedule = [schema "."] schedule
periods_clause = "PERIODS" "=" periodnum
byperiod_clause = "BYPERIOD" "=" period_list
period_list = periodnum ("," periodnum)*
periodnum = 1 through 100

offset = ("+" | "-") ["OFFSET:"] duration_val
span = ("+" | "-" | "^") "SPAN:" duration_val
duration_val = dur-weeks | dur_days
dur_weeks = numofweeks "W"
dur_days = numofdays "D"
numofweeks = 1 through 53
numofdays = 1 through 376
minus = "-"

combined_schedule = schedule_list
REPEAT_INTERVAL.descriptionText: The Scheduler uses a rich calendaring syntax to enable you to define repeating schedules, such as "every Tuesday and Friday at 4:00 p.m." or "the second Wednesday of every month." This calendaring syntax is used in calendaring expressions in the repeat_interval argument of a number of package subprograms. Evaluating a calendaring expression results in a set of discrete timestamps.

RESET_JOB_ARGUMENT_VALUE.descriptionText: This procedure resets (clears) the value previously set to an argument for a job.

RUN_CHAIN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.RUN_CHAIN (
   chain_name                IN VARCHAR2,
   start_steps               IN VARCHAR2,
   job_name                  IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
RUN_CHAIN.descriptionText: This procedure immediately runs a chain or part of a chain by creating a run-once job with the job name given. If no job_name is given, one is generated of the form RUN_CHAIN$_chainnameN, where chainname is the first 8 characters of the chain name and N is an integer.If a list of start steps is given, only those steps are started when the chain begins running. Steps not in the list that would normally have started are skipped and paused (so that they or the steps after them do not run). If start_steps is NULL, then the chain starts normallythat is, it performs an initial evaluation to see which steps to start running).

RUN_JOB.descriptionText: This procedure runs a job immediately.

SET_AGENT_REGISTRATION_PASS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.SET_AGENT_REGISTRATION_PASS (
   registration_password   IN VARCHAR2,
   expiration_date         IN TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT NULL,
   max_uses                IN NUMBER DEFAULT NULL);
SET_AGENT_REGISTRATION_PASS.descriptionText: This procedure sets the agent registration password for a database. A Scheduler agent must register with the database before the database can submit jobs to the agent. The agent must provide this password when registering.

SET_ATTRIBUTE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.SET_ATTRIBUTE (
   name           IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute      IN VARCHAR2,
   value          IN {BOOLEAN|DATE|TIMESTAMP|
                        TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE|TIMESTAMP WITH LOCAL TIME ZONE|
                        INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND});

DBMS_SCHEDULER.SET_ATTRIBUTE (
   name           IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute      IN VARCHAR2,
   value          IN VARCHAR2,
   value2         IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SET_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure modifies an attribute of a Scheduler object. It is overloaded to accept values of various types. To set an attribute to NULL, use the SET_ATTRIBUTE_NULL procedure. The attributes that can be set depend on the object being altered. All object attributes can be changed, except the object name.

SET_ATTRIBUTE_NULL.descriptionText: This procedure sets an attribute of an object to NULL. The attributes that can be set depend on the object being altered. If the object is enabled, it is disabled before being altered and reenabled afterward. If the object cannot be reenabled, an error is generated and the object is left in a disabled state.

SET_JOB_ANYDATA_VALUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.SET_JOB_ANYDATA_VALUE (
   job_name                IN VARCHAR2,
   argument_position       IN PLS_INTEGER,
   argument_value          IN SYS.ANYDATA);
SET_JOB_ANYDATA_VALUE.descriptionText: This procedure sets the value for an argument of the associated program for a job, encapsulated in an AnyData object. It overrides any default value set for the program argument. NULL is a valid assignment for a program argument. The argument can be specified by position or by name. You can specify by name only when:

SET_JOB_ARGUMENT_VALUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.SET_JOB_ARGUMENT_VALUE (
   job_name                IN VARCHAR2,

   argument_value          IN VARCHAR2);

SET_JOB_ATTRIBUTES.descriptionText: This procedure changes an attribute of a job.

SET_RESOURCE_CONSTRAINT.bodyFullText:

SET_SCHEDULER_ATTRIBUTE.descriptionText: This procedure sets the value of a Scheduler attribute. This takes effect immediately but the resulting changes may not be seen immediately, depending on the attribute affected.

STOP_JOB.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SCHEDULER.STOP_JOB (
   job_name         IN VARCHAR2
   force            IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE
   commit_semantics IN VARCHAR2 DEFAULT 'STOP_ON_FIRST_ERROR');
STOP_JOB.descriptionText: This procedure stops currently running jobs or all jobs in a job class. After stopping the job, the state of a one-time job is set to STOPPED, whereas the state of a repeating job is set to SCHEDULED or COMPLETED, depending on whether the next run of the job is scheduled.

stepname [NOT] SUCCEEDED

DBMS_SERVER_ALERT.EXPAND_MESSAGE(
   user_language            IN   VARCHAR2,

CREATE_SERVICE.bodyFullText:

   parameter_array            IN svc_parameter_array);
CREATE_SERVICE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a service name in the data dictionary. Services are also created in the data dictionary implicitly when you set the service in the service_name parameter or by means of the ALTER SYSTEM SET SERVICE_NAMES command.

DELETE_SERVICE.descriptionText: This procedure deletes a service from the data dictionary.

DISCONNECT_SESSION.descriptionText: This procedure disconnects sessions with the named service at the current instance.

MODIFY_SERVICE.descriptionText: This procedure modifies an existing service.

START_SERVICE.descriptionText: This procedure starts a service. In Oracle RAC, implementing this option acts on the instance specified.

CLEAR_IDENTIFIER.descriptionText: This procedure removes the set_client_id in the session.

CLOSE_DATABASE_LINK.descriptionText: This procedure closes an open database link. It is equivalent to the following SQL statement:

FREE_UNUSED_USER_MEMORY.descriptionText: This procedure reclaims unused memory after performing operations requiring large amounts of memory (more than 100K).

GET_PACKAGE_MEMORY_UTILIZATION.bodyFullText:

   owner_names     OUT NOCOPY LNAME_ARRAY,
   unit_names      OUT NOCOPY LNAME_ARRAY,
   unit_types      OUT NOCOPY INTEGER_ARRAY,
   used_amounts    OUT NOCOPY INTEGER_ARRAY,
   free_amounts    OUT NOCOPY INTEGER_ARRAY);
GET_PACKAGE_MEMORY_UTILIZATION.descriptionText: This procedure describes static package memory usage.

IS_ROLE_ENABLED.descriptionText: This function determines if the named role is enabled for this session.

IS_SESSION_ALIVE.descriptionText: This function determines if the specified session is active.

MODIFY_PACKAGE_STATE.descriptionText: This procedure is used to perform various actions (as specified by the action_flags parameter) on the session state of all PL/SQL program units active in the session. This takes effect after the PL/SQL call that made the current invocation finishes running. The procedure uses the DBMS_SESSION constants listed in Table 143-13.

RESET_PACKAGE.descriptionText: This procedure de-instantiates all packages in this session. It frees the package state.

SESSION_TRACE_DISABLE.descriptionText: This procedure resets the session-level SQL trace for the session from which it was called. Client ID and service/module/action traces are not affected.

SESSION_TRACE_ENABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SESSION.SESSION_TRACE_ENABLE(
   waits     IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE,
   binds     IN   BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE, 
   plan_stat IN   VARCHAR2 DEFAULT NULL);
SESSION_TRACE_ENABLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables session-level SQL trace for the invoking session. Invoking this procedure results in SQL tracing of every SQL statement issued by the session.

SET_CONTEXT.descriptionText: This procedure sets the context, of which there are four types: session local, globally initialized, externally initialized, and globally accessed.

SET_EDITION_DEFERRED.descriptionText: This procedure requests a switch to the specified edition. The switch takes effect at the end of the current client call.

SET_IDENTIFIER.descriptionText: This procedure sets the client ID in the session.

SET_NLS.descriptionText: This procedure sets up your Globalization Support (NLS). It is equivalent to the following SQL statement:

SET_ROLE.descriptionText: This procedure enables and disables roles. It is equivalent to the SET ROLE SQL statement.

SET_SQL_TRACE.descriptionText: This procedure turns tracing on or off. It is equivalent to the following SQL statement:

UNIQUE_SESSION_ID.descriptionText: This function returns an identifier that is unique for all sessions currently connected to this database. Multiple calls to this function during the same session always return the same result.

ABORTED_REQUEST_THRESHOLD.descriptionText: This procedure sets the aborted request threshold for the shared pool.

KEEP.descriptionText: This procedure keeps an object in the shared pool. Once an object has been kept in the shared pool, it is not subject to aging out of the pool. This may be useful for frequently used large objects. When large objects are brought into the shared pool, several objects may need to be aged out to create a contiguous area large enough.

MARKHOT.descriptionText: This procedure marks a library cache object as a hot object.

PURGE.descriptionText: This procedure purges the named object or specified heap(s) of the object.

SIZES.descriptionText: This procedure shows objects in the shared_pool that are larger than the specified size. The name of the object is also given, which can be used as an argument to either the KEEP or UNKEEP calls.

UNKEEP.descriptionText: This procedure unkeeps the named object.

UNMARKHOT.descriptionText: This procedure unmarks a library cache object as a hot object.

ASA_RECOMMENDATIONS.bodyFullText:

ASA_RECOMMENDATIONS.descriptionText: This function returns recommendations using the stored results of the auto segment advisor. This function returns results from the latest run on any given object.

Either the space usage totals will be retrieved from Automatic Workload Repository Facilities (AWRF), or the current space usage will be computed and combined with space usage deltas retrieved from AWRF.

You can calculate usage for LOBs, LOB PARTITIONS and LOB SUBPARTITIONS. This procedure can only be used on tablespaces that are created with auto segment space management. The bitmap blocks, segment header, and extent map blocks are not accounted for by this procedure. Note that this overload cannot be used on SECUREFILE LOBs.

This procedure verifies segments created in Automatic Segment Space Management (ASSM) tablespaces.

   ts_option         IN POSITIVE,
   segment_option    IN POSITIVE DEFAULT NULL);

DROP_EMPTY_SEGMENTS.bodyFullText:

   schema_name       IN     VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL,
   table_name        IN     VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL,
   partition_name    IN     VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL);

MATERIALIZE_DEFERRED_SEGMENTS.bodyFullText:

   schema_name       IN     VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL,
   table_name        IN     VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL,
   partition_name    IN     VARCHAR2   DEFAULT NULL);
MATERIALIZE_DEFERRED_SEGMENTS.descriptionText: This procedure materializes segments for tables and table fragments with deferred segment creation and their dependent objects.

SEGMENT_CORRUPT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.SEGMENT_CORRUPT (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   header_relative_file    IN    POSITIVE,
   header_block            IN    POSITIVE,
   corrupt_option          IN    POSITIVE  DEFAULT SEGMENT_MARK_CORRUPT);
SEGMENT_CORRUPT.descriptionText: This procedure marks the segment corrupt or valid so that appropriate error recovery can be done. It cannot be used on the SYSTEM tablespace.

SEGMENT_DROP_CORRUPT.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.SEGMENT_DROP_CORRUPT (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   header_relative_file    IN    POSITIVE,
   header_block            IN    POSITIVE);
SEGMENT_DROP_CORRUPT.descriptionText: This procedure drops a segment currently marked corrupt (without reclaiming space). For this to work, the segment must be marked temporary. To mark a corrupt segment as temporary, issue a DROP command on the segment.

SEGMENT_DUMP.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.SEGMENT_DUMP (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   header_relative_file    IN    POSITIVE,
   header_block            IN    POSITIVE,
   dump_option             IN    POSITIVE  DEFAULT SEGMENT_DUMP_EXTENT_MAP);
SEGMENT_DUMP.descriptionText: This procedure dumps the segment header and bitmap blocks of a specific segment to the location specified in the USER_DUMP_DEST initialization parameter.

SEGMENT_VERIFY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.SEGMENT_VERIFY (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   header_relative_file    IN    POSITIVE,
   header_block            IN    POSITIVE,
   verify_option           IN    POSITIVE  DEFAULT SEGMENT_VERIFY_EXTENTS);
SEGMENT_VERIFY.descriptionText: This procedure checks the consistency of the segment extent map with the tablespace file bitmaps.

TABLESPACE_FIX_BITMAPS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_FIX_BITMAPS (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   dbarange_relative_file  IN    POSITIVE,
   dbarange_begin_block    IN    POSITIVE,
   dbarange_end_block      IN    POSITIVE,
   fix_option              IN    POSITIVE);
TABLESPACE_FIX_BITMAPS.descriptionText: This procedure marks the appropriate block range (extent) as free or used in bitmap. It cannot be used on the SYSTEM tablespace.

TABLESPACE_FIX_SEGMENT_STATES.descriptionText: This procedure fixes the state of the segments in a tablespace in which migration was aborted. During tablespace migration to or from local, the segments are put in a transient state. If migration is aborted, then the segment states are corrected by SMON when event 10906 is set. A database with segments in such a transient state cannot be downgraded. The procedure can be used to fix the state of such segments.

TABLESPACE_MIGRATE_FROM_LOCAL.descriptionText: This procedure migrates a locally managed tablespace to a dictionary-managed tablespace.

TABLESPACE_MIGRATE_TO_LOCAL.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_MIGRATE_TO_LOCAL (
   tablespace_name     IN     VARCHAR2,
   unit_size           IN     POSITIVE DEFAULT NULL,
   rfno                IN     POSITIVE DEFAULT NULL);
TABLESPACE_MIGRATE_TO_LOCAL.descriptionText: This procedure migrates the tablespace from a dictionary-managed format to a locally managed format. Tablespaces migrated to locally managed format are user managed.

TABLESPACE_REBUILD_BITMAPS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_REBUILD_BITMAPS (
   tablespace_name         IN    VARCHAR2,
   bitmap_relative_file    IN    POSITIVE   DEFAULT NULL,
   bitmap_block            IN    POSITIVE   DEFAULT NULL);
TABLESPACE_REBUILD_BITMAPS.descriptionText: This procedure rebuilds the appropriate bitmaps. If no bitmap block is specified, then it rebuilds all bitmaps for the given tablespace.

TABLESPACE_REBUILD_QUOTAS.descriptionText: This procedure rebuilds quotas for the given tablespace.

TABLESPACE_RELOCATE_BITMAPS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPACE_ADMIN.TABLESPACE_RELOCATE_BITMAPS (
   tablespace_name    IN      VARCHAR2,
   filno              IN      POSITIVE,
   blkno              IN      POSITIVE);
TABLESPACE_RELOCATE_BITMAPS.descriptionText: This procedure relocates the bitmaps to the destination specified.

TABLESPACE_VERIFY.descriptionText: This procedure verifies that the bitmaps and extent maps for the segments in the tablespace are synchronized.

ALTER_SQL_PLAN_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPD.ALTER_SQL_PLAN_DIRECTIVE (
   directive_id        IN     NUMBER,
   attribute_name      IN     VARCHAR2,
   attribute_value     IN     VARCHAR2);
ALTER_SQL_PLAN_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure changes different attributes of a SQL plan directive.

CREATE_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPD.CREATE_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE (
   table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
   table_owner        IN VARCHAR2  := USER,
   tablespace_name    IN VARCHAR2  := NULL);
CREATE_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a staging table into which to pack (export) SQL plan directives.

DROP_SQL_PLAN_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure drops a SQL plan directive.

FLUSH_SQL_PLAN_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure allows for manual flushing of the SQL plan directives that are automatically recorded in SGA memory while executing SQL statements. The information recorded in the SGA is periodically flushed by an Oracle background process. This procedure provides a way to flush the information manually.

GET_PREFS.descriptionText: This function returns the value for the specified preferences for SQL plan directives.

PACK_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPD.PACK_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE (
   table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
   table_owner        IN VARCHAR2  := USER
   directive_id       IN NUMBER    := NULL,
   obj_list           IN OBJECTTAB := NULL) 
 RETURN NUMBER
PACK_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This function packs (exports) SQL plan directives into a staging table.

SET_PREFS.descriptionText: This procedure allows the setting of different preferences for SQL plan directives.

UNPACK_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPD.UNPACK_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE (
   table_name         IN VARCHAR2,
   table_owner        IN VARCHAR2  := USER,
   directive_id       IN NUMBER    := NULL,
   obj_list           IN OBJECTTAB := NULL) 
 RETURN NUMBER
UNPACK_STGTAB_DIRECTIVE.descriptionText: This procedure unpacks (imports) SQL plan directives from a staging table.

ACCEPT_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.ACCEPT_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE  (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   object_id       IN  NUMBER    := NULL,
   task_owner      IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   force           IN  BOOLEAN   := FALSE);
ACCEPT_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.descriptionText: The procedure accepts a plan based on the recommendation of an evolve task.

ALTER_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.ALTER_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE (
   sql_handle        IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   plan_name         IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   attribute_name    IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute_value   IN VARCHAR2)
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
ALTER_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.descriptionText: This function changes an attribute of a single plan or all plans associated with a SQL statement using the attribute name/value format.

CANCEL_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The procedure cancels a currently executing evolve task. All intermediate results are removed from the task.

CONFIGURE.descriptionText: This procedure sets configuration options for SQL management base, in parameter/value format. This function can be called numerous times, each time setting a different configuration option.

CREATE_EVOLVE_TASK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.CREATE_EVOLVE_TASK (
   sql_handle    IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   plan_name     IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   time_limit    IN  NUMBER    := DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT,
   task_name     IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   description   IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL)
  RETURN VARCHAR2;

DBMS_SPM.CREATE_EVOLVE_TASK (
   plan_list     IN  DBMS_SPM.NAME_LIST,
   time_limit    IN  NUMBER    := DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT,
   task_name     IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   description   IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL)
  RETURN VARCHAR2;
CREATE_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The function has two overloads, both of which create an advisor task and sets its parameters. This version which takes a SQL handle creates an evolve task in order to evolve one or more plans for a given SQL statement.

CREATE_STGTAB_BASELINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.CREATE_STGTAB_BASELINE (
   table_name        IN VARCHAR2,
   table_owner       IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   tablespace_name   IN VARCHAR2 := NULL);
CREATE_STGTAB_BASELINE.descriptionText: This procedure creates a staging table used for transporting SQL plan baselines from one system to another.

DROP_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The procedure drops an evolved task.

DROP_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.DROP_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE (
   sql_handle     IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   plan_name      IN VARCHAR2 := NULL)
RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
DROP_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.descriptionText: This function drops a single plan, or all plans associated with a SQL statement.

EVOLVE_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.EVOLVE_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE (
   sql_handle   IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   plan_name    IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   time_limit   IN INTEGER  := DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT,
   verify       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES',
   commit       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
  RETURN CLOB;

DBMS_SPM.EVOLVE_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE (
   plan_list    IN DBMS_SPM.NAME_LIST,
   time_limit   IN INTEGER  := DBMS_SPM.AUTO_LIMIT,
   verify       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES',
   commit       IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
  RETURN CLOB;
EVOLVE_SQL_PLAN_BASELINE.descriptionText: This function evolves SQL plan baselines associated with one or more SQL statements. A SQL plan baseline is evolved when one or more of its non-accepted plans is changed to an accepted plan or plans. If interrogated by the user (parameter verify =\'YE\'), the execution performance of each non-accepted plan is compared against the performance of a plan chosen from the associated SQL plan baseline. If the non-accepted plan performance is found to be better than SQL plan baseline performance, the non-accepted plan is changed to an accepted plan provided such action is permitted by the user (parameter commit =\'YE\').

EXECUTE_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The function executes a previously created evolve task.

IMPLEMENT_EVOLVE_TASK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.IMPLEMENT_EVOLVE_TASK  (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,
   task_owner      IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   execution_name  IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   force           IN BOOLEAN    := FALSE)
 RETURN NUMBER;
IMPLEMENT_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The function implements all the actions recommended by an evolve task.

INTERRUPT_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The procedure interrupts a currently executing evolve task. The task ends its operations as at a normal exit and the user can access the intermediate results. The task can be resumed later.

LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   sql_id            IN  VARCHAR2,
   plan_hash_value   IN  NUMBER   := NULL,
   sql_text          IN  CLOB,
   fixed             IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled           IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;

DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   sql_id            IN  VARCHAR2,
   plan_hash_value   IN  NUMBER   := NULL,
   sql_handle        IN  VARCHAR2,
   fixed             IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled           IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;

DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   sql_id            IN  VARCHAR2,
   plan_hash_value   IN  NUMBER   := NULL,
   fixed             IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled           IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
 RETURN PLS_INTEGER;

DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE (
   attribute_name   IN VARCHAR2,
   attribute_value  IN VARCHAR2,
   fixed            IN VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled          IN VARCHAR2 := 'YES')
  RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
LOAD_PLANS_FROM_CURSOR_CACHE.descriptionText: This function loads one or more plans present in the cursor cache for a SQL statement, or a set of SQL statements. It has four overloads: using SQL statement text, using SQL handle, using SQL ID, or using attribute_name and attribute_value pair.

LOAD_PLANS_FROM_SQLSET.bodyNoDefault:
sqlset_name => $1
	, sqlset_owner => $2
	, basic_filter => $3
	, fixed => $4
	, enabled => $5
	, commit_rows => $6
LOAD_PLANS_FROM_SQLSET.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.LOAD_PLANS_FROM_SQLSET (
   sqlset_name      IN  VARCHAR2,
   sqlset_owner     IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   basic_filter     IN  VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   fixed            IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO',
   enabled          IN  VARCHAR2 := 'YES'
   commit_rows      IN  NUMBER   := 1000)
RETURN PLS_INTEGER;
LOAD_PLANS_FROM_SQLSET.descriptionText: This function loads plans stored in a SQL tuning set (STS) into SQL plan baselines. The plans loaded from STS are not verified for performance but added as accepted plans to existing or new SQL plan baselines. This function can be used to seed SQL management base with new SQL plan baselines.

MIGRATE_STORED_OUTLINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.MIGRATE_STORED_OUTLINE (
   attribute_name     IN  VARCHAR2,
   attribute_value    IN  CLOB,
   fixed              IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO')
 RETURN CLOB;

DBMS_SPM.MIGRATE_STORED_OUTLINE (
   outln_list         IN  DBMS_SPM.NAME_LIST,
   fixed              IN  VARCHAR2 := 'NO')
 RETURN CLOB;
MIGRATE_STORED_OUTLINE.descriptionText: This function migrates stored outlines for one or more SQL statements to plan baselines in the SQL management base (SMB). Users can specify which stored outline(s) to be migrated based on outline name, SQL text, or outline category, or migrate all stored outlines in the system to SQL plan baselines.

PACK_STGTAB_BASELINE.bodyNoDefault:
table_name => $1
	, table_owner => $2
	, sql_handle => $3
	, plan_name => $4
	, sql_text => $5
	, creator => $6
	, enabled => $7
	, accepted => $8
	, fixed => $9
	, module => $10
	, action => $11
PACK_STGTAB_BASELINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.PACK_STGTAB_BASELINE (
   table_name       IN VARCHAR2,
   table_owner      IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   sql_handle       IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   plan_name        IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   sql_text         IN CLOB     := NULL,
   creator          IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,   origin           IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   enabled          IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   accepted         IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   fixed            IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   module           IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   action           IN VARCHAR2 := NULL)
RETURN NUMBER;
PACK_STGTAB_BASELINE.descriptionText: This function packs (exports) SQL plan baselines from SQL management base into a staging table.

REPORT_AUTO_EVOLVE_TASK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.REPORT_AUTO_EVOLVE_TASK  (
   type            IN  VARCHAR2  := TYPE_TEXT,
   level           IN  VARCHAR2  := LEVEL_TYPICAL,
   section         IN  VARCHAR2  := SECTION_ALL,

   execution_name  IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL)
 RETURN CLOB;
REPORT_AUTO_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The procedure displays the results of an execution of an automatic evolve task.

REPORT_EVOLVE_TASK.bodyNoDefault:
task_name => $1
	, type => $2
	, level => $3
	, section => $4
	, object_id => $5
	, task_owner => $6
	, execution_name => $7
REPORT_EVOLVE_TASK.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.REPORT_EVOLVE_TASK  (
   task_name       IN  VARCHAR2,

 RETURN CLOB;
REPORT_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The procedure displays the results of an evolved task.

RESET_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The procedure resets an evolve task to its initial state. All intermediate results will be removed from the task. Call this procedure on a task that is not currently executing.

RESUME_EVOLVE_TASK.descriptionText: The procedure resumes a previously interrupted task.

SET_EVOLVE_TASK_PARAMETER.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.SET_EVOLVE_TASK_PARAMETER  (
   task_name     IN  VARCHAR2,
   parameter     IN  VARCHAR2,
   value         IN  NUMBER);

DBMS_SPM.SET_EVOLVE_TASK_PARAMETER  (
   task_name     IN  VARCHAR2  := NULL,
   parameter     IN  VARCHAR2,
   value         IN  VARCHAR2);
SET_EVOLVE_TASK_PARAMETER.descriptionText: The procedure sets a parameter of an evolve task, either a NUMBER or VARCHAR2.

UNPACK_STGTAB_BASELINE.bodyNoDefault:
table_name => $1
	, table_owner => $2
	, sql_handle => $3
	, plan_name => $4
	, sql_text => $5
	, creator => $6
	, enabled => $7
	, accepted => $8
	, fixed => $9
	, module => $10
	, action => $11
UNPACK_STGTAB_BASELINE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.UNPACK_STGTAB_BASELINE (

   table_owner      IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,

   accepted         IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,

   module           IN VARCHAR2 := NULL,
   action           IN VARCHAR2 := NULL)
RETURN NUMBER;
UNPACK_STGTAB_BASELINE.descriptionText: This function unpacks (imports) SQL plan baselines from a staging table into SQL management base.

VERIFY_SHRINK_CANDIDATE_TBF.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SPM.VERIFY_SHRINK_CANDIDATE_TBF(
        SEGMENT_OWNER IN VARCHAR2 
        SEGMENT_NAME IN VARCHAR2 
        SEGMENT_TYPE IN VARCHAR2 
        SHRINK_TARGET_BYTES IN NUMBER 
        PARTITION_NAME IN VARCHAR2 default {unknown}
)
return TABLE

BIND_ARRAY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.BIND_ARRAY ( 
   c                   IN INTEGER, 
   name                IN VARCHAR2, 
   <table_variable>    IN <datatype> 
 [,index1              IN INTEGER, 
   index2              IN INTEGER)] );
BIND_ARRAY.descriptionText: This procedure binds a given value or set of values to a given variable in a cursor, based on the name of the variable in the statement.

BIND_VARIABLE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.BIND_VARIABLE (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   name           IN VARCHAR2,
   value          IN <datatype>);
BIND_VARIABLE.descriptionText: This procedures binds a given value or set of values to a given variable in a cursor, based on the name of the variable in the statement.

CLOSE_CURSOR.descriptionText: This procedure closes a given cursor.

COLUMN_VALUE.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.COLUMN_VALUE (
   c                 IN  INTEGER,
   position          IN  INTEGER,
   value             OUT <datatype> 
 [,column_error      OUT NUMBER] 
 [,actual_length     OUT INTEGER]);
COLUMN_VALUE.descriptionText: This procedure returns the value of the cursor element for a given position in a given cursor. This procedure is used to access the data fetched by calling FETCH_ROWS.

COLUMN_VALUE_LONG.bodyNoDefault:
c => $1
	, position => $2
	, length => $3
	, offset => $4
	, value => $5
	, value_length => $6
COLUMN_VALUE_LONG.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.COLUMN_VALUE_LONG (
   c            IN  INTEGER, 
   position     IN  INTEGER, 
   length       IN  INTEGER, 
   offset       IN  INTEGER,
   value        OUT VARCHAR2,
   value_length OUT INTEGER);
COLUMN_VALUE_LONG.descriptionText: This procedure gets part of the value of a long column.

DEFINE_ARRAY.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_ARRAY (
   c           IN INTEGER, 
   position    IN INTEGER,
   <table_variable>    IN <datatype> 
   cnt         IN INTEGER, 
   lower_bnd   IN INTEGER);
DEFINE_ARRAY.descriptionText: This procedure defines the collection for column into which you want to fetch rows (with a FETCH_ROWS call). This procedure lets you do batch fetching of rows from a single SELECT statement. A single fetch call brings over a number of rows into the PL/SQL aggregate object.

DEFINE_COLUMN.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN <datatype>);
DEFINE_COLUMN.descriptionText: This procedure defines a column to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

DEFINE_COLUMN_CHAR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN_CHAR (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN CHAR CHARACTER SET ANY_CS,
   column_size    IN INTEGER);
DEFINE_COLUMN_CHAR.descriptionText: This procedure defines a column with CHAR data to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

DEFINE_COLUMN_LONG.descriptionText: This procedure defines a LONG column for a SELECT cursor. The column being defined is identified by its relative position in the SELECT list of the statement for the given cursor. The type of the COLUMN value determines the type of the column being defined.

DEFINE_COLUMN_RAW.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN_RAW (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN RAW,
   column_size    IN INTEGER);
DEFINE_COLUMN_RAW.descriptionText: This procedure defines a column of type RAW to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

DEFINE_COLUMN_ROWID.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DEFINE_COLUMN_ROWID (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   position       IN INTEGER,
   column         IN ROWID);
DEFINE_COLUMN_ROWID.descriptionText: This procedure defines a column of type ROWID to be selected from the given cursor. This procedure is only used with SELECT cursors.

DESCRIBE_COLUMNS.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DESCRIBE_COLUMNS ( 
   c              IN  INTEGER, 
   col_cnt        OUT INTEGER, 
   desc_t         OUT DESC_TAB);
DESCRIBE_COLUMNS.descriptionText: This procedure describes the columns for a cursor opened and parsed through DBMS_SQL.

DESCRIBE_COLUMNS2.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DESCRIBE_COLUMNS2 ( 
   c              IN  INTEGER, 
   col_cnt        OUT INTEGER, 
   desc_t         OUT DESC_TAB2);
DESCRIBE_COLUMNS2.descriptionText: This procedure describes the specified column. This is an alternative to DESCRIBE_COLUMNS Procedure.

DESCRIBE_COLUMNS3.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.DESCRIBE_COLUMNS3 ( 
   c              IN  INTEGER, 
   col_cnt        OUT INTEGER, 
   desc_t         OUT DESC_TAB3);
DESCRIBE_COLUMNS3.descriptionText: This procedure describes the specified column. This is an alternative to DESCRIBE_COLUMNS Procedure.

EXECUTE.descriptionText: This function executes a given cursor. This function accepts the ID number of the cursor and returns the number of rows processed. The return value is only valid for INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statements; for other types of statements, including DDL, the return value is undefined and must be ignored.

EXECUTE_AND_FETCH.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.EXECUTE_AND_FETCH (
   c              IN INTEGER,
   exact          IN BOOLEAN DEFAULT FALSE)
  RETURN INTEGER;
EXECUTE_AND_FETCH.descriptionText: This function executes the given cursor and fetches rows. This function provides the same functionality as calling EXECUTE and then calling FETCH_ROWS. Calling EXECUTE_AND_FETCH instead, however, may reduce the number of network round-trips when used against a remote database.

FETCH_ROWS.descriptionText: This function fetches a row from a given cursor. You can call FETCH_ROWS repeatedly as long as there are rows remaining to be fetched. These rows are retrieved into a buffer, and must be read by calling COLUMN_VALUE, for each column, after each call to FETCH_ROWS.

GET_NEXT_RESULT.descriptionText: This procedure gets the statement of the next result returned to the caller of the recursive statement or, if this caller sets itself as the client for the recursive statement, the next result returned to this caller as client. The statements are returned in same order as they are returned by the RETURN_RESULT Procedures.

IS_OPEN.descriptionText: This function checks to see if the given cursor is currently open.

LAST_ERROR_POSITION.descriptionText: This function returns the byte offset in the SQL statement text where the error occurred. The first character in the SQL statement is at position 0.

LAST_ROW_COUNT.descriptionText: This function returns the cumulative count of the number of rows fetched.

LAST_ROW_ID.descriptionText: This function returns the ROWID of the last row processed.

LAST_SQL_FUNCTION_CODE.descriptionText: This function returns the SQL function code for the statement. These codes are listed in the Oracle Call Interface Programme\'s Guide.

OPEN_CURSOR.bodyFullText:
DBMS_SQL.OPEN_CURSOR (
   treat_as_client_for_results    IN     BOOLEAN    DEFAULT FALSE) 
  RETURN INTEGER;

DBMS_SQL.OPEN_CURSOR (
   security_level                 IN     INTEGER,
   treat_as_client_for_results    IN     BOOLEAN    DEFAULT FALSE) 
  RETURN INTEGER;
OPEN_CURSOR.descriptionText: This function opens a new cursor. The security_level parameter allows for application of fine-grained control to the security of the opened cursor.

PARSE.bodyNoDefault:
c => $1
	, statement => $2
	, language_flag => $3
	, edition => $4
	, apply_crossedition_trigger => $5
	, fire_apply_trigger => $6
	, schema => $7
	, container => $8
